Bottle. Pale brown huge frothy head. All black body, seems thick, like syrup. Heavy malty aroma. Not sweet, medium dry. Medium sweet flavour, roasted malt, some coffee and licorice. Full bodied. Dry and slightly bitter finish. (At home, 19.02.09)
UPDATED: MAR 6, 2009 On tap at Uber.  Pours black with a decent beige head.  Aroma is smoky malt.  Flavors of smoked meat, chocolate, roasted malt.  Thick mouthfeel, roasty finish.

Bottle. Thanks a lot for getting me this, Anker! Very dark brown almost black with a longlasting reddish brown head. Lots of roasted malt in nose with notes of dark fruit and peat. Very roasty flavour with some coffee notes and liqourice. Creamy body.

11.2 oz bottle.  Pours dark brown with amber hue.  Head is creamy tan.  Smells of roasted coffee, toffee, and sweet cream.  Tastes about the same.  Lots of roasted coffee, molasses, smokey, anise, burnt chocolate.  Very nice beer.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with a fair head. Leaves lacing on the side of the glass. Aroma is roasted malts, coffee, and expresso. Flavor is rich and creamy. Lots of malts and chocolate tastes. Very well balanced beer.

Bottle poured at Belmont Station. Dark brown body with a smooth khaki head. Sweeter nose of dark chocolate, faint coffee, cake, and licorice. Really well built all around, balanced but focused on the malts throughout. Finishes a bit earthy, almost like burnt chocolate.

Tap at St. Urhos Pub, Helsinki. 
Pours black with a dense brown medium sized head. 
Aroma is sweet liquorice, roasted coffee, roasted malt and hints of honey.
Flavor is liquorice and roasted coffee, with a soft bitter liquorice finish. 
A very nice porter.

Tap at Memphis Taproom.  Pours a deep black with a medium bubbly deep tan head that left some lacing.  Aroma of tart cherry, dark chocolate, caramel, tobacco and nuts.  Flavor of dark chocolate, tart cherry notes, tobacco, earthy, nuts, vanilla, smooth and creamy.

On tap at Deep Ellum, body is a pure black with a thin creamy tan head.  There is a subtle malty aroma with notes of espresso, peat and a bit of dusty smoke.  Flavors of smokey rich coffee and hot choco dominate the pallate with notes of vanilla, honey and dry grass and dried dark fruits.  The pure black body goes down with a thin silky mouthfeel with little or no alcohol soak.  Really a nice balanced beer with some complex flavors poking around.
Bottle reads Sinebrychoff Porter IV.  Purchased at Castle in Westport a while back.  Pour dark, nice burnt layers of flavor.  Hard to recall all the details.

Sinebrychoff bottled in 2000.  Pours a thick dark brown.  Nose is deep and rich with bourbon, chocolate and black licorice.  Flavor is nice and roasty, without being smoked.  A little bitter and a little sweet.  This is a lot better than I thought it would be.

Pours a jet black with a nice deep tan head that sustains very well... Mildly sweet aroma, not a ton going on in the nose... Complex flavors, not your run of the mill chocolate/coffee/roasty porter... Dark fruits galore, hints of chocolate, hints of vanilla, a touch bitter, somewhat roasty, this is a true wintertime porter, i couldnt fathom drinking this in the summer, even though it is quite easy drinking... Medium full mouthfeel that is quite drinkable and leaves a lingering somewhat roasty carbonated finish... Very Very Good...

Pours a pitch black with a lovely dark brown head with good retention. Aroma is sweet and chocolaty, with lots of licorice - yum! Tastes lovely and sweet and more chocolate and light roasted character, it has a middling watery taste but a milky latte/espresso taste lingering in the finish. Body is thick and creamy with appropriate carbonation. I really like the roastiness and creaminess here - very nicely done!

(bottle - 330 ml) Rich black pour with a fluffy tan head. Aroma is light and subtle with hints of chocolate malts, dark fruits, roasted malts, coffee, and toffee. Very complex. Flavor is briefly sweet at the start but goes to a bitter and chocolaty middle mixed with a lot of dark fruit peels and bitter, burnt malts. Finishes bitter and lingers for a while.

Bottle at Novare Res.
Pours a dark dark brown with a tan head.  This beer is super malty smelling with sweet aromas of chocolate and coffee.  Taste is sweet at first and ends with a bitter chocolate finish.  Serious dark malt in this porter, theres a TON of flavor in this beer.

sugared alcohol. toffee. slight dairy element, chocolate milk-like. Upon warming, maybe a touch of dark cherries. Very nice and subtle.

Dark black pour with a very tan thick head that clings to the side of the glass.

Taste is strong in magnitude up front, a mix of the many aromas fading into a decidedly bitter chocolate. Good, but I think if it had a slightly more mellow fruit sweetness to the end, it would be superb.

Palate is rich.

On tap at Maxs in Baltimore.  Poured a deep deep brown with a nice tan head.  Aroma is malt and roast, a bit of coffee and some chocolate.  Flavor is heavy on the roast.  Almost a burnt sour flavor, but strangely appealing.  Maybe you have to be in the right mood for this beer, but not bad.  A touch metallic.

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2012 Bottle - 2000.  Pours a motor oil black with little head.  Dark chocolate (as compared to milk chocolate) and burnt coffee aroma.  The body isnt as thick as expected.  Cocoa, slightly sour, roasted molasses,  Theres a burnt coffee taste at the end.  A mild bit of oxidation but very tasty.

October 2012 - Just cracked another 2000 bottle. Its past its prime. Drink em if you got em.

Dark brown with ruby highlights, chunky almond coloured head. Aroma is cocoa, char, and clay. Lovely creamy palate of coffee and pruney dark stewed fruits. Medium bitter finish of good length. A fantastic porter!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text:
THOUGHTS: Bought it for the nice label and the fact that its a porter. Didnt realize it was a baltic porter. A nice surprise. Also I didnt realize it was Finnish, so it was a really nice surprise, because its my first finnish beer.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a dark brown that was completely opaque black in the glass with a large, rocky and foamy, dark tan head that kept a fair sheet and left excellent lacing. The aroma was mostly hot cocoa mix, light roasted and burnt malts, light to moderate hops, light yeast and sour fruits. The flavor started out slightly sweet and sour, and finished sour and bitter with an average to long duration. There was light burnt and roasted malt, cocoa powder, sour fruit and bitter earthy, metallic hops. The medium body was oily then dry with tingly carbonation and a slightly metallic, slightly chalky and lightly astringent finish.

2008 Bottle - Pours a watery dk dk brown with a dissipating tan head, aroma is coffee and chocolate malt...aroma is similar with some soy and light hop bitters, certainly not sweet...finishes with a char bitter finish...pretty dry, nice...
bottled. pitch black with small brown head. tastes very burned. best when ice cold. when warm, metallic.

Aroma is strong and smoky with a salty undertone, like fine coffee mixed with miso. It pours black as motor oil with a thick dark ecru head that is fine-bubbled but doesnt stick around. Flavor is like smoky coffee with nutty and unsweetened chocolate hints, and just a touch of sweetness and a bit of hop bitterness. Texture is smooth and tingly, and just a bit on the watery side. Not too shabby.
bottle. smells of chocolate and roast. taste is roast, coffee, chocolate leaving a slight chalky finish. warmness from alcohol. great beer.
Bottle. Black. Small beige head. Smells choclate. Tastes chocolate and port with small tartness in the aftertaste. I think this beer has a little too much carbonation.
Bottle, #431. Black pour with medium head. Roasty malt aroma and flavor with ah bit of chocolate and high alcohol flavor. Good brew overall.

Caramelly notes with very light chocolate and abv on the nose. A deed dark brown pour with huge frothy head and lace.More caramel on the flavor with a very nice smooth bitter finish. Light hints of abv and hint of chocolate but that is all a very interesting beer to say the least.

12oz bottle at the Crosswoods Winking Lizard.  Pours pitch black with a huge tan head.  Super malty aroma, but there is some roast character there.  Malty sweet flavor with a nice roasty coffee finish.  Expensive, but worth it.

Black, firm tanned head. Nicely smooth aroma has little coffee, dried fruits, smoke, cocoa, molasses and loads of leather. Similar flavor with quite tangy hoppiness in the finish, not all that pleasant. Medium to full bodied, round filling mouthfeel. I remember this one being better on tap. A good nightcap, though far from the top.

UPDATED: MAY 16, 2009 Bought for $3.99.  Viscous, dark brown pour with heavy cream-colored lacing. Nose of roasted malt, bakers chocolate, sweet raisin, and earthiness.  Palate is smooth, though thin when swishing the beer around in mouth.  I tasted sweet malt and dark chocolate notes to start, then transitioning to a bitter, ashy profile by the finish.  There was also something unusual going on here.  Through the mid-palate, I kept tasting something resembling coca-cola, with perhaps a touch of straw and chalkiness.  Overall, I initially enjoyed the palate, though as I started to realize its "thinness" it became bothersome.  I am impressed by this baltic porter, something does seem a touch strange.
Blackish color with a strong roasty-sweet aroma.  Flavor is roasty, smooth, but lacks a real bite to finish things off.  Good, but I’ve never been super-impressed with this one.

Deep black coloured body with a nice sized large dense brown head - very nice. Aroma of metal, blood, roasted malt, caramel and nuts. Medium-bodied; Strong roasted malt flavour with nuts and raisin flavour really strong. Caramel and coffee come through as well. Aftertaste shows bitter characteristics with coffee and chocolate too. Overall, a good beer - not my favourite baltic, but definitely good to try! I sampled this super old (like 5 year old) bottle that was stored in my fridge on 29 October 2008.

Pitch black body with a very thick milk chocolate head and nice concentric rings of lacing.  Smoky roasty malt with a slight alcohol tinge.  The body is light but smooth, slight dark roasted malt, waves of earthy coffee and a finish of sweet chocolate.  Fantastic smooth finish would have actually suspected this was a lager not an ale.

Bottled in 1997, bottle #2451: I found this beauty in my cellar during a recent inventory so thanks whoever gave it to me! 11 years old and this beer is great! Jet black in the pour with a light tan head that faded fast. Lots of roast in the aroma with dark fruit as well and sweet malt. Flavor is the samewith maybe a little coffee-ness to it. The finish is quick and dry with some lingering to it. No real pronounced hops in this one but then it is 11 years old as of this review. Wonderful beer which now I’m going to go have to find elsewhere as it was my one and only.

Black color with nice beige head. Aromas of roasted malt, chocolate and rye. Flavor is sweet roasted malty with lots of coffee and some chocolate. Also a slight flavor of fruits can be tasted. Dry in the end with very nice bite of hops. Great mouthfeel. Amazingly delicious for a Finnish beer.

Bottle courtesy of SoLan.  Pours a pitch black with a 2 finger chocolate milk colored head and nice delicate lacing.  Nose is roasted malt, coffee grounds, toasted oats and some light dark fruits.  Taste is ashy malt, cocoa, roasted coffee beans, salty black licorice and some bitter hops finishing it out.  Full, creamy mouth feel.  A great Baltic porter  thanks Alan!
Somewhat sweet and malty.  Deep black.  I’m definitely tasting some licorice.  A decent smell but I’ve had more interesting Porter’s.

Thanks to lithy for the bottle!Beautiful sepia color with a short-lived yet rich, creamy tan head. Theres some roast malt and chocolate in the nose, but its driven by very sweet, sugary fruit: plum, raisin, near grape juice. Flavor is similarly fruity, more coffee present than chocolate, long in sweet malt. Full bodied and rich, its not quite as smooth as Id like. Still a great beer; my main regret was it being only 33cl.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2008 Bottle. Pitch black colour with a nice brown head. Roasted malt and liquorice aroma. The flavour is sweet, liquorice and roasted malt with hints of coffee and dark chocolate. Long, roasted and bitter aftertaste. Full-bodied and smooth mouthfeel. Delicious Porter.

(Bottle).  Sweet malt aroma, with fruit and alcohol.  Black in color, light brown head.   Tangy fruity flavor, also coffee and caramel.  Very long finish, including alcohol warming.  Potent and very tasty.
33 cl bottle. Totally black. Well balanced taste with aroma of coffee and chocolate. Beautiful porter! Best finnish beer.

330 ml bottle. Pitch black, with a thick creamy light brown head. Sweet aroma of roasted malts, dark fruits, coffee and dark chocolate. THe flavour is like the aroma, with a nice bitter and slightly burned hoppy finish. Smooth mouthfeel. By far the best Finnish beer I’ve tasted.

33 cl bottle. Pours completely black, with some ruby highlights. Wonderful thick, llonglasting and tan head, I’d say almost brown. Amazing, rich and complex nose, which even improves and develpos more tones when the temprarture increases a little bit. A sweet caramel and vanilla background, where coffee and bitter chocolate notes are well embedded, followed by fruits (figs, plums). The flavor starts lightly sweet but turns roasty bitter with a alcoholic warmth in the finish. Medium and almost silky body, pretty dry.
Wonderful porter.

33cl bottle poured into an English pint.  KP (Sinebrychoff Porter IV) pours extremely dark brown with a thin tan head.  I smells like licorice, prunes and a touch of alcohol.  There’s also a hint of warm maple syrup or possible molasses.  The body is just the right consistency for a porter, a tad thinner than a stout.  The taste is a superbly balanced mixture of roasted grains, chocolate and just a hint of dark fruits.  This beer is extremely drinkable and can easily be held up as a role-model for brewers world wide.
Bottle @Novare w/ mary and Brian.  Very smooth and drinkable porter with balnaced roasted grains and malt sweetness.  Would like to try this again paried with a nice roast.

(Finland) Pours a nice black color with zero head. The aroma is of roasted malts, chocolate, vanilla, and caramel. Taste of chocolate big time,with caramel, and malts. The mouthfeel is very smooth and ends with a slight bitterness. This porter is well balanced and is recommended.  :)

33cl. pours black with a nice creamy looking tan head. aroma is roasted malt cocoa and a hint of vanilla. mouthful is dark bitter chocolate, some coffee, with a lingering bitter finish. very nice robust baltic porter.

330ml Bottle:  Aroma of chocolate, smoke, and burnt malts.  Poured black in color with a medium to large-sized, dense, rocky, creamy brown head that lasted throughout.  Opaque.  Excellent lacing.  Lightly sweet flavor.  Tastes of chocolate, malts, slight soy sauce, sour milk, cream, roasting, a tad of vanilla, and a hint of bitter hops.  Medium to full body.  Thick, creamy, slightly dry texture.  Soft carbonation.  Malty, chocolate finish is a bit dry.

Thank you, mcbackus!  Pours black with a fairly large brown head, lasting ring of foam.  Aroma of dark chocolate, chocolate milk, almonds, vanilla, coffee-astringency, toast,  just really really nice overall.  Tastes similar with dark chocolate, dark rye toast, nuts, coffee, wood and finishes slightly astringent at first.  Thankfully the finish evolves into this really nice bitter toasted almond flavor.  Really nice aftertaste effectively counters any astringent elements.  Medium bodied, but the creaminess makes this feel substantial and the carbonation is also moderate.  Quite good!

Bottle.  Pretty much a total black pour wtih a pretty big head.  Aroma of delicious toastiness and coffee.  I smell some vanilla and wood as well.  Taste is fruity and malty as hell with a predictable flavor of chcolate.  Good beer indeed.

33cl bottle: Heartily pours from the bottle to the glass.  Builds a deep, near black body and a rising, foamy, thick brown head.  Intensely roasted nose is worth savoring.  Loads of fresh coffee, brown sugar, caramel, sweet fudge, brownie batter, strong vanilla.  Thick, viscous body with a very clean finish.  I love this style - loaded with complexity but is easy drinking and finishes fairly clean on the palate.  Finishes with a touch of ripe plums and bitter grapefruit.

Smells of sweet, dark fruits, and roasted malt.  Pours a thick black with a small tan head that diminishes quickly.  Taste is more dark fruit, roasted ashy malt, and chocolate.  Smooth and sweet with hardly any bitterness.  Long, dry finish of chocolate and nuts.  Excellent after-taste that lingers well after swallowing.  My favorite Baltic Porter so far.

11.2 oz. bottle from Wine Warehouse. This is the Sinebrychoff Porter IV label. Nearly black pour with a one finger head. Roasted malt aroma with coffee and milky notes. Taste is roasted malts with coffee, caramel, milky, nutty and bitter hop notes. Medium body.
A .33L bottle from Alko. Dark brown colour. Brown head with big bubbles. Some metal in the taste. Taste of mocca-coffee. Not too much sugar.
Bottle. Really dark pour with a small chocolate malt head. Very roasty aroma with licorice hints. Bitter chocolate and coffee flavor ending dry with hints of nut. Very nice beer.

330 ml bottle from my secret santa (summer 08). shared with jessem. pours black with a small tan head. soft carbonation. aromas are all roasted malts. chocolate, anise, roasted barley, caramel. flavours are similar with the caramel really showing. a little thin, a little to sweet. some astrigency. not a bad brew but this one might have been past its prime.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2009 33cl bottle shared with Matt7215 and his brother, his bottle (thanks Matt). May or may not have been a 2003 or 2004 vintage. Pours a nice inky brown with a small mocha head. Aroma is major anise, prunes, alcohol, and roasty malts. The flavour is really nice, and in one word I would describe it as balanced. Big sweetness up front, dark fruits, roasty malt, hint of coffee, but with a very dry astringent finish that works perfectly with the preceding sweetness. No hint of booze whatsoever. Decently complex, though I wouldnt say that its a stand-out in that respect. Ive been craving this style, and its something Id rather have on a brisk winter evening, but for the time being it hit the spot, and I really enjoyed it. Top notch stuff I wish I could get locally!

On tap @ De Geuzen and De Paas, 2007. Black beer, creamy beige head. Aroma of coffee, roasted malts, chocolate, some sweetness. Flavour is sweet at first, coffee, liquorice, chocolate. Slightly metallic. Bitter coffee finish and aftertaste. Thick and oily palate/mouthfeel. Very complex and extremely nice beer.
One of the best if not the best beer in Finland. Delicious liquid chocolate ryebread with a nicely dry aftertaste. Winter warmer, summer dessert and simply a great beer.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a dark coffee color with a medium sized dark tan head.  Has the aroma of dark chocolate, coffee and cherries.  Flavor follows in that respective order, with the fruit flavor on the finish.  Pretty heavily bodied.  Coffee flavor predominant in the aftertaste.  A good selection.
It poured very dark brown/black. It had a dark brown head to it. There was a strong aroma of fruit. It tastes like mocha/chocolate, with a bitter finish.

Pours black with deep brown edges and mocha foam.  Aromas of dark fruit, alcohol, coffee & dark chocolates.  Flavor is very sweet malt, caramel & chocolate with plenty of bitter roast espresso & dusty chocolate near the finish.  Finishes rather dry with a slight mineral note.

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2008 Bottle thanks to Santa. Pours a pure black body with a medium light brown head. The aroma is full of a boozy combination of dark fruit and expresso. The taste is very nice; tons of sweet fruits, blackberries mostly, some coffee and chocolates, and a dry and toasted malt finish. A very nice Porter for sure. I could live in Finland just to drink these, plus all those hot Finnish girls.

Bottle. Blackish beer with a nice tan head. Big chocolate, caramel, malt aroma. Caramel malt flavor with light roast/espresso and slight mineral notes. Medium bodied. Lingering mineral, caramel, and light roast.

Best of the night, shared by Fidel. Pours almost black with a decent, dark tan head. This was a big beer in nose and flavor. Complexity flowed with chocolate, molasses, roasted malt, finishing a bit dry and subtle bitterness. Very good beer.
Black, light roasted malt, Molasses, caramel, dark chocolate, coffee, dry, slight hops.

Got a bottle at Spuyten Duyvil. Pours black with a tan head. Aroma of dark malts and hops. The flavor has tons of dark malts and bitter hops, but not too bitter. I didn’t think it was as creamy as other people have said... it has a certain dryness in the finish that left me just wanting more. A really great beer.

Pours a deep dark black with a medium tan head.  This beer has a malty, somewhat sweet aroma that is populated by chocolate, coffee, vanilla.  The flavor is quite similar, with a creamy texture.  A quite wonderful beer.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2008 pours dark black with medium tan head.
Aroma is very appetizing coffee & molasses, some chocolate, rye bread, light vanilla.
Flavour is quite bitter after that sweet aroma. Burnt malt, bitter choc., molasses and vanilla. well blended alc.
A little thin tasting for me though.

This not really a porter, more like stout.
The flavour says "burnt rye bread" to me.
Not really my favourite

Bottle purchased at Gordons n New London, CT. 

Pours tar, thin tan head. Aroma is molasses, malt, coffee, anise, vanilla, caramel, pine. Flavor is the same and smoky chocolatey with roastiness. This is a damn good porter even if I do say so myself

Bottle. Pours black with creamy and long-lasting brown head. Nice lace formation. Aromas are deep, rye bread-like roasted malts and sour cocoa beans Also a hint of dried fruits. Flavor starts sour and finishes chalky dry with a medium bitteration and wonderful chocolate aroma. Hops are somehow earthy and robust but it fits well with this beer. Alcohol is very well hidden. Slick and thin texture, medium body. One of the best finish beers. Distinctive character of this beer is always as enjoyable.

Bottle. Appearance is cola black with a small brown head.  Aroma is chocolate, but flavor is somewhere between soy sauce and ketchup with elements of coffee.  That combination is not necessarily unappealing, though.  Dry and thin, with a chalky and earthy aftertaste.  Doesnt do it for me right now, but it leaves me intrigued.
11.2oz bottle, bottled 1998. Pours pitch black in color with very thin brown head. Aroma sweet, molasses and malt. Taste coffee, malasses and bitter chocolate with dry finish.

From By The Bottle in Vancouver, WA--Poured a rich dark, thick, nightmare black with a pillowy gray-brown head.  Sweet Baltic nose with a roasted and little metallic bite, but subtle.  Complex flavors of chalky chocolate, carob, dry wine, and roasted almond.  Excellent finish of smooth, crisp and robust dark decadence.

Thanks to Girlie for this one.  Last one of the bunch that she sent to me for my birthday.  Agree with the previous post - Scandanavian brewers have nailed this style.  Gorgeous deep/dark pour and a fluffy, long-lasting rich tan head.  Takes a good 5 minutes for the head to dissipate.  Aroma is slightly sweet, with the heavy aroma of roasted malt.  Slight hoppiness in the aroma as well.  Flavor is consistent with aroma - strong roasted flavors with coffee and slight chocolate.  Nice bitterness on the back of the palate to round out the full flavor of this one.  Excellent brew.

Bottle at the brickstore. I think the norwegians have the porter style figured out. This one is pretty intense not only in its aroma but also in its flavor. Roasted malt aromas with some coffee and slight cocoas as well.  Flavor is much of the same but has a little sweetness and a bitterness to it as well.  Very enjoyable, complex, and smooth.

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2008 Aroma is roasted and burnt malts, cocoa, and coffee. Strong and creamy flavor with a lot of roasted and burnt malts, chocolate, coffee and hops. Very smooth mouthfeel is relatively thin.

This has got to be the best porter that I have ever tried, and I am not a big fan of that style, but this is delicious.  This is a big malty treat, lots of roasted chocolate, caramel, coffee and other delights, perhaps a bit of toffee, but extremely rich and creamy.  Delightful!

1st impression was wow!!!  There is as much flavor in this as any beer will ever have.  The aroma is undeniable.  Malts ahoy, some chocolate, maybe molasses, and coffee.  Its appearance was a little disappointing, it was rather nil on the head scale, with a black body, and minimal head.  The flavor is overwhelming, with alchohol, expresso, dark chocolate, malt, and maybe toffee or caramel.  Its feel is a bit bitter, and at times a bit too much, but all in all that should be expected a bit given its complexity.  Nice!

Pours a rich brown color with tannish frothy head the fades quickly.  Aroma is of semi-sweet chocolate, carmel, and molasses.  Taste is caramel, molasses, traces of dark fruit and earth.  Alcohol is well hidden but the earthiness lends to a bit of a dry finish.  Still, it holds its own.
dark beer with a solid head.  Although oak/wood flavors convey with the beer, it has little finish and is disappointing...

Black in color with a lasting tan off white head which fades rather fast, Aroma very molasses with chocolate notes with small hints of alcohol. Taste very watered down with hints of the chocolate and semi sticky molasses.
Bottle. Pours soild black with a large, lasting, tan head. Aroma of chocolate, roasted malts, plums an dates. Soft carbonation. One of my absolute favorites!

(cleaning out my beer bottle collection as pictured in my profile and utilizing ratebeer.com)
As I recall, this was one of my favorite porters.  I actually kept this bottle.  Incredible mix of chocolate, dark malts, and roasted coffee.

Pours a dark chocolate brown with a large chocolate head that fades rather quickly leaving spotty lacing.  Aroma is chocolate, dark malts, bourbon, and a bit of molasses.  The taste is very smooth.....almost a bit too flat, but very drinkable - chocolate, roasted/burnt malts.  Very balanced in my book.  A great porter for the price.

Bottle at The Diamond. This beer poured very dark, almost black with a red hue to it. Small to no head. The nose was almost whiskey like, but not the taste. A delicious and complex flavor, with hints of chocolate and burnt malts.  Great carbonation too. What surprised me was how thin the mouthful was, but how intense  and full the flavor is, and with so much carbonation it is almost soda like.

Amazing! Smells great (dark chocolate, hoppy, malty), looks great (deeeeeep black-brown and the head retains that color) and tastes great! I have learned a special Finnish phrase and this beer makes me say it: Henkilökunta! Lisää viinaa! (Staff! we need more liquor!)

bottle at home now.
color: black nice light brown head
Scent:roasted malts hops
Taste: symphony of sticky roasted malts, hops and dryness long roasted malts and hops aftertaste.
Pours a deep burgundy with a thick tan head. Aroma is sweet malt, coffee, and roasted grain. Taste is roasted grain, chocolate malt, coffee and molasses.Slightly dry coffee aftertaste. Solid porter.

Pours black with a thick brown head. Aromas of burnt malts and chocolate. Flavor is sweet chocolate with smokey burnt malts. Full body with minimal carbonation and a thick,creamy mouthfeel with a bitter finish. Very good, would have again.

Bottle Pours out a blck topped with a nice tan head. A sweet aroma of dark chocolate and roast. Tast of not much dark chocolate but more sweet milk chocolate. Also picked up some molases. A little bitter on the end. A tasty Baltic Porter.

*did not mind, would not buy*

aroma: nice rich buttery dark malts. sweet molases app: dark neat head that ran away quick. flavor: soy molases earthy dark sweet flavors. its ok.. its a baltic! palate: its fine OA: i liked it ok, not for me.

Wow. Pours black as forever,with a thick brown head that lingers. Incipit is a complex burst of spicy florals. Mouthfeel is oily in the best sense. Has a gentle bitterness that doesnt really become noticeable until the finish... (just like sex!).

Draught, 2007. The color is nearly black, the head is firm and lasting. The aroma brings chocolate to mind. Smooth mouthfeel. The taste is a complex combination of chocolate, roasted coffee beans and a touch of smoke. An astounding beer, considering it comes from a major producer of run-of-the-mill lager

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2009 nice thick black malt drink. big head. coffee. slight bitterness in the end should be more thick. surprisingly good. 

HBF09 RA-version: sour and bitter, toasty black malts shine through, sweetish watery salty, lemony / sweet grapefruit. flat mouth (no carbonation)

Pours black with a lasting thick, tan head.  Aroma of molasses, caramel, and coffee,  Taste of caramel and coffee slides into a lasting bitter finish.  Med mouthfeel.  Very nice porter.  Mouthfeel could be thicker.  Thats my only complaint.

Bottle thanks to DragonStout. Poured a thick brown color with ruby highlights and a thin tan head that receded to a ring.  Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, and light fruit.  Lightly sweet malt entry leads into a relatively bland, chalky chocolate flavor with a bit of fruitiness on the finish.  Smooth, but somewhat watery.  Not really bad, just pretty plain.  Thanks Brian.

Bottle.Appealing big, frothy tan head atop a black body. The aroma is full with roasted malt, chocolate and caramel with hints of creamed coffee and caramel and a touch of smoke. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. The finish is moderately to heavily bitter with a bit of sweetness. Fairly long lasting. Medium body and lively carbonation. The texture is between watery and creamy  a nice balance. Well constructed.
deep black with 1/4 inch brown head... intresting fruity aroma with a real dark smoked flavor when you drink it.

Total black, half-inch brown head that fades to big-bubble scum and lasts considerably.  Aroma a bit subdued, dark chocolate, roastiness, earthy hops.  Excellent taste:  dark chocolate and roasted malt interplay,  caramelization, coffee in the middle palate and coffee-bitter finish. Very slightly sweet upfront.  Rasping on the tongue, aftertaste has a slight lactose-like sweetness.  Moderate to high carbonation, sits well on the tongue, not watery but not thick.

Color of this beer is deep black. Heads color is like creamy mocha and it is quite thin but lasting. Aromas are dark chokolate, roasted malts. Flavors are roughly roasted malts and rye bread, a little bit of metallic nuance. You can find a hint of chokolate from the flavor also. Nice bitterness in the aftertaste. Palate is quite smooth, slightly carbonated and gooey.
Black color with a good sized brown head.Aromas are of European chocolate and roasted malts. Flavors are coffee, dark chocolate, wood/smoke.

The aroma of this tar colored beer is exquisite.  It smells of rich chocolate, almost like a chocolate cheesecake, with overtones of roasted coffee.  The flavor is more robust, there is a strong, smoky roasted flavor and some bitter kick in the background.  Some flavor almost reminescent of powdered espresso beans is noticeable.  The finish is all roasted maltiness and coffee flavor.  This is a great porter, which is full bodied but drinkable, and smooth yet potently flavorful.  Seek this out if you enjoy dark beers.
Pours black with a large brown head. Strong, malty, roasted taste with aromas of coffee, smoke and dark chocolate. Surprisingly thin mouthfeel but definitely not watery. Slightly carbonated.

330ml Bottle- Black in colour with a chocolatey brown head reminiscent of a cup of cocoa. Coffee and chocolate in the aroma. Rich taste with plain chocolate and roasted coffee with a pleasing creaminess in the lightly malty finish. Very enjoyable and whilst it is rich and full bodied, it is also smooth and easy to drink.

bottle. pours black with creamy tan head. aroma of oats, espresso, and lots of dark sugars. oaty, brown sugar, coffee, and chocolate flavors. the sugar really reminds me of the sugar used in dark lord. light-med silky body. low carbonation feel. smooth beer although a tad grainy finish.
Pours a dark brown with a small tan head, nice lacing. Aroma of smoke, chocolate, and nuts. Flavor seems a little dull.

Pours think oil black with a medium creamy mocha head.  Some smoked peat and slightly metallic aroma.  Really an excellent porter.  Creamy chocolate and some caramel, little smokey with a very noticeable metallic hoppy edge. Not exactly what I was expecting. Really an excellent fast drinking porter but I prefer my fullers =).  (this one reminds me of a nicer version of sierras porter)

Pours a very dark black with foamy coffee colored head.  Beautiful aroma of smoky maltiness, chocolate, nut and toast.  This is a very complex beer with lots of smoky malty flavor.  Hints of chocolate, toast, nut and roasted coffee.

Viscous inky pour--coated my glass as I swirled.  Smoky, chocolately, and nutty on the nose and the palate.  Also notes of smoke, sourness, soy, and a little grease.  A classic baltic porter from what I can tell.
Courtesy of Dragonstout. Pours a very dark brown with a dark thin head. Aroma is mostly burnt grain. Tastes of cocoa, burnt, nuts, little spice. Mouth feel is full bodied with a silk texture.

Pours a deep black with good sized chocolate head. Nice lacing. Very nice to look at. Big whiff of chocolate at first, some oily scents, dark and rich fruit, smoke. Flavor is smokey, fruity, herbal hops... like a rich dark chocolate bar. Mouthfeel is thick anbd wonderful. Peppery alcohol round out some of the other flavors without being overly assertive. Finishes like a piece of chocolate, leaving the mouth watering and craving more.

Thanks to gunhaver for this bottle.

As it waterfalls out of the bottle you can tell this beer is very dark brown but in the glass it is pitch black. The head struggles to form upwards through this beers viscosity, but manages a nice inch of foam. It leaves a thin smattering of lacing before settling to an amorphous cap atop the liquid.

The nose is bitter chocolate, with a sizable dose of roastiness. Some espresso comes through as well.

Taste is far more roasty than the aroma, with some unsweetened chocolate and a charcoal/metallic finish. Pretty classic porter here. I dont get a lot of dark fruit anywhere in this beer.

Carbonation is pretty smooth but the finish is sticky. The metallic note also hampers the drinkability.

This pours a pitch black color with a thin tan head that leaves behind a little lacing. The aroma is of roasted malts, some smoke, sweet and dark chocolate, and a hint of coffee as well. The taste is a perfect blend of chocolate, roastiness, coffee, and raisins. Some bitter hops on the back end balance things out and keep it from being overly sweet. The body is very thick with a viscous mouthfeel that leads to sweet finish with roastiness left behind. I could drink this porter over and over. This is a great brew.

11.2 oz bottle thanks to drmatt.  Pours a dark black with a light brown head.  Smell is of coffee and some alcohol.  Taste was coffee with some chocolate and roasty malts.  Towards the end it tasted a little like cola.  Mouthfeel was medium.  This was a nice representation of the style.

11.2oz bottle from 2000, purchased at the Wine Market, D.C. A big thick pour, with just a trace of carbonation still around. Heavy peat and roast malt aroma, like this ones been sitting in old wood for centuries. Nice big chocolate malts give it some life, with a slightly smoky background. A good one.

Bottle.  This is good stuff I was glad I picked up having never heard of it before.  Nice big cocoa colored head on this opaque dark brown brew.  Appears stout like with little lacing.  Potent malty aroma with hints of cherry and chocolate.  Big roast flavor, bitter finish with burnt toast character.  Medium bodied with a strong lingering presence.  Creamy.
Pitch black with plums, brandy, tobacco, and dark cherries jumping out of the sensational nose. Port, tobacco, cherries on a thin mouth.  Tasted a bit oxidized, so would like to retry when fresher.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2008 Bottle, 33cl. Opaque black, even against light you can’t see through it. Pours with a creamy tan head. A sweet aroma, with notes of coffee, dark chocolate, roasted malt, licorice, caramel, rye bread. A full-bodied, smooth and thick mouthfeel with a long finish, with a taste of coffee, dark chocolate and bittering hops.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2008 Black. Handsome rocky brown head. Dry cocoa aroma. Flavor is rye bread with cocoa, burned malt and a hint of hops. Dry dark chocolate aftertaste. Medium, extremely dry body. Moderate carbonation. All in all, far too dry for me to really enjoy it.
Black color with a thick rich tan head.  Aromas of oak, molasses, and dark chocolate.  Rich dark chocolate flavor with notes of coffee

Sept. 2006 - I must be crazy, but I wasnt crazy about this one.  Pour was jet black, with some reddish highlights, no head or lacing.  Strong aroma of licorice and chocolate.  Mouthfeel wasnt creamy and was kinda flat and dull.  The flavor was just too sweet...with some odd fruitiness and licorice which overpowered what little roastiness and coffee which was present.  I prefer Baltika 6 for my Baltic Porter cravings, by far.

Nice aroma, mainly sweet chocolate with molasses overtones.  Black motor oil body topped with creamy latte head, thick rings of lace all the way down. Dark fruits, but sweeter and more intense - like dried plums and figs coated with molasses. This is combined with coffee, milk chocolate, and so much more. It ends roasty and kind of burnt (in a good way), finishes off with a slightly bitter taste. Good beer.

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2011 In short: Superior porter.  very smooth but tasty with molasses, figs, wood, tobaccos and everything.
How: Bottle 12oz from after4ever, thanks a lot Tom.  Age unknown but consumed shortly after receiving it.
The look: Black body with a medium tan head with medium retention
In long: Strong molasses nose.  The soft but full body is richly malted with upfront molasses and figs flavours and lots of small bubbles.  Slowly chocolate joins the party as the beer warms-up.  An unexpected but pleasant sensation of wood/barrel although Im pretty sure it isnt barrel aged.  Surprisingly smooth yet very.  The woody hops dry out the beer more than provide bitterness and thats just fine.  As the beer kept warming up more and more woody and tobacco flavours were coming through and it kept getting better.  Currently it is both the highest rated and most rated Finland beer and deservingly so.  A great beer when you let warm-up to (north-america) room temperature, which by Finland standard is probably considered boiling hot.

Bottle. Pours opaque black-brown with thin tobacco-colored head. Aroma is thick rye - like a rye loaf rising in the oven - attendent mildly funky yeast, some toasted notes round out the aroma along with light milk chocolate and nutty chestnut aromas. Flavor is muted roasted flavors - thick rich coffee, light smokiness- melded with soft bread texture. All around subtle and subdued character, no flavors distinctively stand out. Finish has pine sap-like resiny bitternesss, a hint of dark fruit tartness and lingering smoke flavors. Palate is full, slightly creamy and mildly oily. A beautiful beer for #300.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2008 Ugly little bottle. Pours dark brown, with very little head. Thin braids of lacing remain on the glass; quickly diminish. The aroma is very sweet, but not overwhelming. Chocolate, cotton candy, oozing caramel. Very good. Flavor is great: candied sugars enveloped by nougaty caramel and of course chocolate. A roasted quality is present, but subdued enough to not be a distraction. Great mouthfeel, enough of a kick to balance out the sweetness in the flavors. A warm, chocolatey aftertaste. Very good.

330ml bottle served in a brandy snifter. Poured an opaque black with quickly dissipating tan head. Not a lot of carbonation. Fruity aroma with some cocoa and molasses. Nice creamy mouthfeel. Plenty of malt, slightly sweet. Some roasted malt. A little hop bitterness in the middle and finish to balance the malt. Long dry lingering finish of coffee. Good stuff.

Looks as gorgeous as a beer can: thick, black, several fingers worth of frothy tan head and intricate lacing. Artwork in a glass. Aroma is cold cave, damp, delicious, cellar, can, simple. Stunning roasted aftertaste, nuanced, complex, smooth, rich, and moreish. Flavor proceeds along an impressive extended arch with smooth coffee entry, chewy middle, and a lingering burnt finish. Mouthfeel is soft, silky, smooth, and thins out slightly at the end. 100% enjoyment in spite of "starch" being listed as an ingredient on the label (which is billed as Sinebrychoff Porter IV).

33cl bottle labeled as Sinebrychoff Porter IV.  Pours a very dark brown as it flows out of the bottle. Once in the glass, it is a rich black with a tan head. Plenty of molasses in the nose, along with a little malt.  The flavor is of coffee and a little brown sugar.  Medium body with a smooth bitterness. Finish is warm, with a bitter, but not unwelcome, aftertaste.

33 cL bottle, thanks to Grovlam. Pours dark brown with a huge dense light brown head, perfect pour. Light roasted malt, slight alcohol nose and dark malt. Flavour is mild smoked flavour with mild chocolate smoothness and a nice roasted note. Smooth finish with a solid bitterness mixing with roasted malt notes. Beautiful pour, faint aroma and good flavour.
[Courtesy of Grovlam ,session @ yespr] Black with lovely large brown head. Mild aroma of roasted malt, chocolate and smoke. Flavor is smoky with roasted malt, coffee, chocolate and caramel notes.

Bottle [Thanks to Harri for bring it back from Finland] Huge brown creamy head that really lasted. Excellent lacework. Pitch black colour. Aroma of coffee, dark chocolate, roasted malt, grain, oat, hint of dried fruit and what feels like a hint of smoke. Over the palate roasted malt, light bitter liquorish and coffee. Full bodied with an average carbonation and light dry, alcoholic and thick texture. Moderated sweet and bitter flavour. Dark chocolate like bitter finish.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2008 Bottle 33cl labelled as Sinebrychoff Porter IV, from Southern Seasons, Durham, NC. Pours a good dark brown colour with a steady deep tan head. Offers up a typical porter aroma of dark fruits and berries and chocolate malts. Fine flavours of chocolate, and dark roast coffee, with the dark fruits coming through with touches of sweetness.   Has a lingering bitterness on the palate. It was thinner than I was expecting, but still very drinkable.

Bottle at home ... Thanks to Pat ... Deep solid black ... nice roast and lots of alcohol in nose ... roast malt ... bit bitter ... some hop character ... bit over powerful with the balance a bit off but still ok.

[943-20071207] 330mL. Light alcohol aroma has a bit of leafy malt roast. Black body with a long-lasting foamy tan head. Roasty malt flavour has non-rich coffee grain notes. Medium-full body. Quite a nice porter.

Rating #400.  Bottle.  Pours pitch black with a brown head.  Aroma is roasted malt with a bit of chocolate and plum notes detected as well.  Taste is heavy roasted malt up front, with detectable chocolate and dark fruit, and a surprisingly high alcohol burn for the amount of alcohol actually in the beer.  Solid offering, but I was a bit disappointed.

Pitch black with a nougat colored and creamy head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, a light sweetness, dark fruits and a touch of chocolate. The same goes for the flavour, where I also find licorice and a light bitterness in the finish. Its a quite full bodied and warming Baltic porter! Thank you Tom/After4ever - it seems ridicilus to get a Finnish porter all the way from the US - the things we do to get new ratings - tsk, tsk....

I thought that this was going to be like one of those nitro-burning Imperial stouts that are fine for sipping, but not for the sessions that my stupid brother seems to want to have this Christmas. Instead it pours dark with a very bubbly beige head. Aroma was a bit off, and the first sip gave me the metallic taste of pennies in the mouth, but subsequently is starts out with a good fore-flavor of darkish malts with a light and more refreshing (read not dry) finish. Has some smoke to it. Easy drinking.
Very nice dark roasted aroma, but the flavor seems a bit light.  Taste is somewhat reminiscent of diet coke.
Pours black and rather thick. Flavor is rather malty, but definitely not bad. Flavors more in line with chocolate and caramel fall in without much of a coffee influence. Excellent beer.

Pours black with cappachino colored head, big and fluffy slowly settle to a thick film.  Picture perfect lacing.  chocolate and roasted malts on the nose.  thin bodied roasty mouth-feel and chocolatly malty finish.

12 oz bottle courtesy of Dragonstout. Pours a dark brown with a brown head. Nose is of dry chocolate, dark fruits and malts. Tastes of light chocolates and dark fruits and roasted malts.  Some raters have noted soy sauce. I dont get that.  This brew is a bit on the light side, but pretty good.

Pours out black with a big frothy chocolaty head that takes its time before lacing to a thin layer. Looks spectacular. Smells of bakers chocolate, dark fruit, and roasty malt. The taste is crazy, in a very good way. Starts roasty, then transitions into bakers chocolate, then the dark fruit kicks in then washed away by a hop bite that dissapears to a coffee but silky flavor. So smooth in the mouth with a tickle of carbonation. I could drink these all night long.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2007 Bottled in 2000! Still some carbonation left over. Pours opaque black with no head. Aromas of soy sauce, cellar must, salty, black currants, and a cigarette butt right after I went out for a smoke! Soy sauce continues in the flavor as well as some sweet smoked malt, and hints of toffee. Flavor is limited but distinct. Mouthfeel starts off nearly watery but becomes full and chewy towards the end. Soy sauce dominates. Fresh is better but this was quite enjoyable with some sharp cheddar. Notes of Bali Shag (blue) show up in the nose towards the end. Interesting brew.

Bottle.  This beer pours an opaque black in color with a capuchino colored, frothy head.  The aroma is of bitter coffee and burnt chocolate; a fairly standard porter blend.  Tasting is another story.  This beer is a bit too sour, not creamy bitter, just oddly sour.  The other negative is it is too thin.  Good porter in my mind should be on the thicker, slighty oily side.  This is a little too weak.  The finish is clean with a bit of a bite.  All around not bad and drinkable, but not on my list to revisit.
An absolutely great beer from Finland! Great roasted malt flavors with hints of caramel, coffee, and dark chocolate. Worth finding, a truly wonderful beer.

Im seeing a lot of really high ratings for this one.  Heres a counter-statement.
If you like a one-trick pony beer, heres a candidate. This brews singular trick is darkness.
Black. Darker than a black steers tuckuss on a moonless prairie night. As in, very dark.
Some adjectives: licorice, coffee, sorghum molasses, soy sauce. Next!

33cl bottle. Smokestack chalice. Aroma is roasty, plums, ,milk chocolate, a slight lactic tang, and a bit of licorice. As far as I can tell, the color is black with a nice brown head that dies down pretty quickly. Big bodied. Initial taste is malty, with dark milk chocolte, lite dark fruits, and some roast and some tang followed by a  rush of roast, nice maltiness, some tartness, and prunes. The ale yeast and munich are both apparent in this wonderful Baltic Porter.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2009 33 cl, bb L70465N. Opaque black with a huge sugary head. Cocoa, caramel and coffee aroma. Tastes of dry cocoa,  charred wood, lightly sweetened coffee, and some peppery herb. Medium-bodied, chalky, and has some tongue-tingle.

11.2 oz bottle purchased at Spirits RB. Pours a viscous pitch black with a large foamy brown head, the body is great but the head needs a little work. Initial aroma of tobacco, espresso, roastiness and an underlying sweetness to it all. Medium bodied that is light on carbonation and finishes bitter sweet. Very roasty flavor overall with notes of tobacco and a slight burnt flavor but towards the end there is a burst of dark sweetness. Wow I was expecting nothing and got something, something pretty darn good that is.

Bottle 33 cl. Pours an absolute black with a brownish head and an aroma of roasted malt and citrus. Taste is mostly roated malts, with some chocolate some undefined sweetness. Long bitter finish, pretty good!
Black. Dark brown head. Aroma is rich with roasted malt, sweetness... Flavor follows very well, fine balance between dry roasted flavors and the rich sweet malt. Oily feel and long balanced finish.

33cL bottle into pint glass. Pours a deep, dark black with a light, dark tan head that dissipates quickly. Heavy aromas of caramel, butter and roasted malts with a hint of coffee. Flavor is of dark chocolate, toffee, roasted malts, and a slight plum finish. Mouthfeel is thick and chewy. Great Baltic porter.

11-11-07 bottle 
Alcohol molasses and sugar aroma - reminds me of my alcoholic grandmas sugar and gingerbread cookies.  Highly carbonated in comparison to what I was expecting - not heavy at all.  Watery in the finish.  Has a sweet, almost smoky developed flavor though.  Quite light in weight and overly bubbly - but the flavor does actually stand out.  Can taste hints of alcohol as it warms.

Pours nearly black with good sized light bron head. Aroma has hints of straw, burnt coffee adn some sweetness. The taste has plenty of bitterness along with some sweet hints. Nice creamy mouthfeel with a medium body.

bottle thanks to Beerlando
Black pour with a quickly fading bubbly fizzy brown head.  Smell is a touch of soy, molasses, some figgyness and heavily of peat, much like a scotch ale.  Nice medium body that isnt too thin or thick, with a slight worcestershire tastes.  Dull fig flavor as well and tastes too much like a peaty, Mcewans scotch ale or Traquair house to me.  Nicely made beer, but the flavors just arent for me.

As Sinebrychoff Porter IV. Bottle from Ledgers Liquors. Top fermentation! Go Finns! It pours like oil. It smells like dark fruit with a hint of coffee. The color is opaque black with a tan head that didnt stay long. Thin to medium body with creamy, near chewy, carbonation. The flavor is dark roasted malt, coffee, and light stone fruit? Mouthsmackingly good. Its going really well with lox, but the lox smoke may affect the ale flavor. Maybe there is some cola in this. It is very tasty. The finish is not all that dry, has remnants of dark roast, and a hint of hop. Maybe light stone fruit, and more than a hint of hop. I think this ale changes from moment to moment. Its really very, very tasty. Try this before you depart this mortal coil.

Pours a very dark red hued brown with an ample creamy tan head, diminishing slowly, rocky at first.  Fruity dark fruit nose.  Lightly sweet, small acidic roast.  Big prunes and raisins particularly.  Small chocolate and subtle coffee.  A bit of an herbal maybe slightly anise and chicory backdrop.  The mouthfeel isnt super thick and viscous, but not watery, with low carbonation.  A bit of warming. Much bigger roast and roasty acidity than I would have guessed a prior from the nose.  A really biting roast that balances the slightly above average sweetness, which is dominated by dark fruits, raisins and currants with some prunes.  The biting charcoal finish is laced with a touch of anise.  Theres a good deal of complexity in this baltic porter, than that I think Ive previously encountered.  Perhaps the only drawback is that Ill have to drink another beer to not get heartburn from this!  Still, a very lovely beer.  The long finish is so dry and bitter!

Pours a very dark brown through which no light passes through.  The head is very dark brown, with small bubbles and nice retention.  The aroma is strangely citiric, with dominant notes of roasted malts, and charred woods.  The flavor is chewy with chocolate, smoked woods, some mild tannins, and roasted malts.  The flavor is very well balanced and the mouthfeel is very nice with a clean finish and a nice, full body.  Overall, an excellent representation of a style that I do not have often enough.
This is an excellent example of a Baltic Porter.  Probably the best I have ever had.  I like it a little better than Okocim.  Not sure I have ever had a better one...

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2009 Bottle. Dark black body with tan head. Retains head well. Head was bubbly at first and later turned more creamy. This is one of my favorite styles. A taste reveals, dark roasted malt, bittersweet chocolate, bakers chocolate. Powdered cocoa. There are plums, raisins, nuts. but I am most struck by the dark chocolate. Hmmm, I wonder what this one would taste like brandy barrel aged? Only complaint might be that the finish is a bit weak and abrupt. Excellent  Baltic Porter. This is how it is done right!

UPDATED: NOV 23, 2009 33cl bottle.  A very good lookin beer, pours very dark brown with a  big frothy brown head.  Plenty of sticky lacing.  This really came to life after about 15 minutes in the glass.  Aroma is a powerful blend of dark chocolate, dark fruits, malt, coffee.  One of the best Ive encountered so far...I find myself drinking it very slowly so I can continue to take in the aroma.  Shoulda bought two...  Flavor is more of whats in the aroma, very chocolaty.  Sweet.  Very smooth and rich, but not overly heavy.  Ive been hunting a Baltic Porter for a while, and this Sinebrychoff is an amazing beer.  One of the best Ive ever had.
Bottle. Black colour with a tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate. Flavour is hop, roasted, smoked, chocolate, coffee, malt . Nice beer.

Bottled. Poured black with a dark brown head. Aroma was a rich velvet chocolate with coffee and roasted notes. Flavor was a flat chocolate/coffee combo with chocolate being the dominant of the two. Reminded me of a Baltic Porter, and I come to see that is how it is listed here so I pegged that one. Good rich malted body.
Absolutely fantastic porter - best I have ever had.  Great mingling of coffee and chocolate notes along with a few darker fruits.  Will enjoy again and again.

Bottle. (trade w/tbone_) Pours very dark brown, almost black, and is topped by a creamy, beige head. Fruity and slightly oxidized nose, with chocolate and roasted malt. The same goes for the flavor, but theres a weak note of coffee there as well. It finishes quite dry, with chocolate, roasted malt, some fruityness and bitterness. I would like a fuller body on the beer, and also some more hops, but it is definately a nice beer. (070809)

poured thick and heavy with pillowed bubbles covering the surface of the tan head.  milk chocolate aroma.  starch is listed as an ingredient.  what does that mean?  full, rich flavor begins with the sweet roasted malt and fades as the bitterness gains attention.  smooth and creamy throughout.
330ml bottle. Pitch black with a chocolate malt head. Aroma - Malt, prune and other dark fruit. Taste was of dark sweet fruit, coffee, cocoa and a hint of borwn sugar. Very nice.
Very nice roasted taste maybe even little smoky.Finnish has little bit of bitterness. Head is quite rich.

Bottled as Sinebrychoff. Pours black with a thin tan head which leaves some thin lacing.  Aroma is earthy with notes of roasted malt. There is some cocoa and chocolate which hints at things to come. There is almost no carbonation. The nose is sweet and gives way to symphony of earthy flavors. The flavor is extremely complex.  I picked up cocoa, coffee, molasses, and some wood. The finish is slightly bitter. The mouth feel is of a medium body beer.  I found no trace of the 7.2 abv.  It was thinner than I anticipated.  It was extremely smooth. An extraordinary porter.

deep brown so as to appear black. roasted chocolate aroma that is fine. smoky and chocolate flavor with a creamy brown head and consistancy. the palate is excellent as is the appearance. the flavor is verygood and the smokiness eases quite a bit and in short order. wonderful hop finish that announces itself in an understated and inticing way. magnificent!

Pours oily black with muted head.  Super roasted aromas emerge as well as dark fruit scents like raisin, plum and figs, touched with a burnt sugar, coffee and mocha element.A well bodied roasted brew with a warming quality.  Balanced and robust, this porter is very tasty which fits the style quite well and presents a drinkable, quality beer.

(Draught at Akkurat, Stockholm, 21 Sep 2007) Pitch black colour with brief, brown head. Roasted nose with chocolate, coffee, liquorice and modest notes of tar. Roasted, malty taste with notes of chocolate, liquorice, hints of tar and soy sauce. Powerful finish with coffee bitterness and sweetish chocolate notes. Medium to full body, with slightly oily texture. Seriously nice porter.

This dark brown ale poured with a decent long-lasting tan head and a strong malt aroma. The flavor is rather bitter for a porter, but that is offset by the sweetness in the ensuing coffee and caramel malt tastes. Very complex and delicious.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2015 First ratingInitial Rating Date: 9/24/2007Draught at Akkurat, StockholmBlack color, fluffy creamy brown head. Fruity, sweet, roasted scent. Roasted dry coffee and chocolate taste with hints of metal. Smooth mouthfeel, medium bitterness. Was very nice with some chocolate truffel.8/5/8/4/16=4.1Rerate33 cl bottle thanks to deft!On October 2, 2010 - BB 08.04.2011.Pours thick and viscous, black non-see through, medium sized brown head. Sweet, lactic, alcohol, raisin, smooth, chocolate scent, also some salt. Grainy, metallic, chocolate taste, some coffee and loads of roasted malt. Taste starts off almost mild, but change to an evident grainy and roasted malt aftertaste. Strange mix of smooth and fizzy mouthfeel. Medium, a bit dry and harsh, bitterness.8/4/7/3/15=3.7Rerate33 cl bottle thanks to tkrjukoff! BB 17.05.2012, sampled on November 19, 2011.Black color, brown head. Malty, sweet, fudge, grainy scent. Sweet, malty, fudge taste. Fizzy mouthfeel, medium high bitterness.8/3/7/3/15=3.6

Bottled as Sinebrychoff.  Sweet malty aroma with a huge helping of earthy roast that gets down and dirty.  Light appended fruitiness and medium-strength notes of chocolate and caramel.  Opaque motor oil pour with a dark brown head, long-lasting and lacing and rocky - an absolutely gorgeous beer.  Bitter and very dry taste (and after-), heavy roast overtones with very sweet red berry rushing up to offer balance.  Coffee and caramel linger but only deep under the chocolate.  Thin body, smooth feel, and relatively tight alcohol integration.  Feel like some sort of stratigrapher or dendrochronologist counting the rings of lace collected on the glass, and the slowly-diminishing rocky head reminds of ice cream dumped into a glass of A&W.  Superb.

Pours a pitch black with a dark tan head. Nose is a sweet sugary malt with extremely faint roasted bean (coffee and cocoa) qualities to it. Flavor is very unique. Smooth and tough. On the very tail end I get a strong almost tarred earth aftertaste that lingers in my mouth. But before that comes I get a strong silky smooth lightly roasted porter. Feel is thick and with good bubble. It has only been a few minutes and I am halfway through it. Extremely drinkable. An absolutely beautiful brew.

Rich choco-fruity malt aroma with roast.  Good label, impressive caramel head on opaque beer.  Twang/acidity in the aroma.  Smooth, a little metallic - especially the foam.  Tangy, most of the bittering is left to the dark malt.  Nuts, some cocoa.  Very good, but missing hallmarks.  Thick.  Finishes nicely.  Bottle, Ludwigs, Philly.

9/12/2007:  Sinebrychoff Porter IV pours like motor oil that has been used not once, but twice!  It is very dark brown, pretty opaque, and doesnt really have much of a crown.  I think this is a vintage bottle as the carbonation seems to be pretty low as well.  The aroma is great!  It has lots of rich, complex dark malts, semi-sweet chocolate, sweet licorice, some distance char, and maybe even a hint of Dr. Pepper.  The flavor is also quite complex.  It has a deep, darkly roasted maltiness, molasses, carmelized sugar, some wood (probably from the oxidation), char, and smooth chocolate undertones.  The finish is almost like black coffee in both flavor and bitterness.  The mouthfeel of this medium-bodied beer is smooth, but a bit thinner than expected.  This beer is quite good overall, but might be slightly past its prime...
33 cl / 11.2 fl. oz. bottle (7.2% alc./vol.) from Westside Liquors in West Harrison, Indiana.  Rating #584 for this beer...

Bottle - Jet black color with a small quickly diminishing head.  This beer was grea.  Much more malt character than many other Porter.  This gives the beer a really nice character that holds up very well to the molasses and chocolate flavors.  Really weel done.
Sinebrychoff Porter IV. 7.2% alcohol.  Very dark color, head dont last.  Taste malty and somewhat sweet.
Sinebrychoff Porter. Black color with small brown head and nice lacing. Aroma has strong chocolate malts. Flavor is first sweet and then malty and chocolaty as it warmed.

33cl bottle; Nose of chocolate with a molasses note; opaque black with a medium glass-lacing tan head; flavor of a mixture of chocolate, molasses, and some coffee; finish being a very faint hop bitterness. Body is medium; good but not great. A little too molassesy for my taste.
Pitch-black color, nice brown head. Chocolaty, sweet, soft aroma has some berries in it too. Long, multi-dimensional flavor. Very dry and bitter. Coal-like ending. Some espersso notes.

11.2oz, no date.  Deep brown with a two finger tan head, fades to a 1/4" film after a bit..  Loads of semisweet chocolate and molasses in the aroma, some roast, and soy and nuts in the background.  The slightest tinge of spicy alcohol present.  The flavor even has a hint of smokiness--dunno where that came from.  Lots of chocolate and scorched caramel in the flavor, roasted grain and ashy semidry finish.  The alcohol is more apparent than it probably should be (at 7.2%) as it warms.  Low carbonation, medium body.  Very good beer that I have overlooked a few times before at Johns Grocery.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Poured deep brown to black with a frothy coffee con leche head which quickly dissipated.  Aroma was malt, chocolate, and slight alcohol.  Flavor is chocolate with a roasted finish.  Pretty bitter, but nice.  Not that its the greatest, but if you needed a beer to represent the porter style, this would be the one.

Name: Sinebrychoff Porter
Date: 02/12/1999
Mode: Bottle
Source: Taco Mac, Sandy Springs

black, whispy tan head, light alcoholic malt aroma (7.2%), thin body, hint of roasted, touch of chocolate, some complexity, but overly alcoholic

Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 13/20
Rating: 3/5.0Score: **+/4
-------- />
Name: Porterri Porter
Date: 02/10/2005
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting

black with a nice tan head, nice sweet chocolate aroma, rich malt flavor with lots of bitterness, strong bitter sweet chocolate character, 

Aroma: 8/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 16/20
Rating: 3.7/5.0Score: **4
-------- />
The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Black.  I love it.  Nice tan head also.  Oh...my...god...nice chocolate smell.  Looking forward to ths!  Top 3 Porter on my list of Porters.  Just wow.  Not really that carbinated which makes it great!  Chocolateness goodness.  OH MAN!  Also a hint of espresso mixed in it.  Great!
Bottle: Great Porter with the formidable roasted malts taste and heavy alcohol in it.

This beer pours almost pure black with what might be the darkest head I have ever seen.    Aroma is big for a porter and is full of roasted malts.  It hints of a great beer to come.  First sip brings a wide variety of flavors.  Roasted coffee, dark chocolate and dark fruit jump out.  A light dry bitterness remains long after the sip is gone.  Ratebeer samplers give this a 98% and I can only imagine how good the top 2% is!  This beer is amazing and takes the style to some wonderful heights.

2000 bottle from kmweaver, consumed 7/22/07. Black body with a small tan head. Lightly oxidized, sherry nose with anise, caramel and chocolate. The flavor is lightly sweet, roasted with some dark fruits, toffee and dark chocolates. Medium body is very soft with light carbonation. This has held up quite nicely.

33 cl bottle from a great trade with Stegosaurus - thanks Joe. Opaque black with ruby highlights and a creamy thick brown head.  Dark fruity aroma with some coffee notes and spice. Thick and luxuriously chewy, with some lingering bitterness and a little oiliness. nicely balanced with a solid malt base and assertive spicy bitterness. A real treat, deserving of its reputation.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ as Sinebrychoff Porter IV. Not very strong aroma but there are black berries, moccha and some hops. Black color, thick light brown head, good lace. Sweet, chocolate, coffee, soft bitterness. Thick and soft mouthfeel. In the far finish hops are increasing which is nice.

Props to KAggie97 for this tasty beverage. Black as night with a deep coffee colored head, very thick. Biscuits, roasted coffee and chocolate malt aromas. Body is medium with nice tight carbonation. Roasted barley, coffee and bitterness on the palate.
Fantastic brew.

Keg on tap at The Poshoorn, Maastricht. Black with tan head. This beer seemed to be the guest beer in several Maastricht pubs on the day, a great find. Full of heavily roasted malt giving strong coffee notes with chocolate malt bitterness, in fact intensely bitter. On the beer warming up a slight tartness developed giving further depth. Yum.

Massive creamy head recedes around the edges leaving the centre of the foam looking like a poached egg floating within. The flavour is predominantly dry and bitter with some coffee notes coming through. The texture is rich and oily giving a great mouthfeel.

Rated 7/31/07.  Pours into the glass like the darkest, dirtiest motor oil.  There is an audible "glug, glug, glug" sound as it flows from the bottle.  The body is black, period.  Black as night.  There is a small mocha colored head that leaves behind some very nice lacing.  The aroma is a harmonious mix of sweet chocolate, stewed raisons, anise, faint smoke, and a hint of dark fruits (maybe cherries).  The flavor is surprisingly void of the dark fruits, but roasted barley, coffee, and molasses take their place.  Bitter hops do well to balance out the sugary sweetness.  The palate on this beer is about as thick and viscous as any Ive encountered to date.  Excellent brew!

Bottle.  Body is a dark brown color with a pretty big two/three finger head of foam and froth.  Aromas are chocolatey with some dark fruit mixed in... maybe a little peat and molasses, too.  Flavor is fairly sweet... picks up much more on the prune/dark fruit than the smokey peat and molasses notes from the nose.  I cant really pick up the alcohol at all, and Im not perceiving any warmth off it, either.  Could be just a little more complex in terms of aromas and flavor/development to get higher marks.  Still, very nice.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Tap, in Pothuiske in Maastricht. Thick black with soft long lasting head. Sweet chocolate touffee taste with roasted malt. It tastes like a bit overroasted, but very pleasant. A bit too light for a Baltic Porter but very enjoyable even on a summer evening.

Bottle. Opaque black with a bubbly and foamy head. Aroma is chocolate and roasted malts, also a hint of cappuccino coffee. Flavor is a bit smoked but in a nice way, a very warming drink. Coffee and salty liquorice (finnish salmiakki) also come out in the flavor. A very sturdy beer with a malty finish.

A forced drink at 1:15 on a monday because the beer broke open on me when moving beers.  Opaque black with tan head.   Aroma is doughy, alc, smoked dark malts, and some dark choclate.  Flavor is dark fruits, black licorice, choclate, alc, smoke, and little bitterness.  Med thin body with no carb to speak of but that could be due to the whole dropping process.  Overall I pretty nice but will have to rerate at a later date.
Tap @ In de Wildeman. Aroma of blackcurrant and coffee. Opaque black coloured with a brown, thin head. Taste is sweet with a quite hard bitter finish. Malty, coffee, some fruits in it.
Black, beige head. Aromas of coffee. Flavours: coffee, coffee cream, caramel, blackbarries. Lots of bitterness, dry bitter aftertaste.

33 cl bottle.  Best before 6/27/03 !  How old is this sucker?  Pours an oily black with a big bubbled, mocha head.  Thick lace ladders.  Licorice, tobacco and black coffee.  Hints of marzipan as it warms.  Medium body with a touch of carb.  Scrumptious bittersweet chocolate, baked apple and plum.  Finishes espresso with lime peel.  Maybe my oldest beer.  Seems to have a more concentrated flavor but ive not tried a fresh one.

Tap @ In de Wildeman. Dark black color, short dark brown head. Aroma of some coffee and licorice, quite weak though, some candy sugar, dark fruit. Very clean and very bitter taste, not expected because hops are not abundant in aroma. Very malty, coffee. Clean bitter palate.

Pours a black color with a dark brown head. Aroma is roasted malts and weak coffee. Taste is actualy pretty sweet with dark candi sugar and dark fruits (mostly plums) hitting the tounge. A light roasted flavor hits at the very end of the sip. Didnt taste the soy sauce that others were getting in fact I thought that this beer was very sweet and not really salty at all. Good stuff and would have again.

Bu à Mc Kays Public House à Bar harbor, Maine, en boutelle de 33 cl. Brune très foncée, peu de collet. Arome de chocolat fuge malté, un peu de caramel anglais. Goût de malte torrifier, chocolat mi-amère et quelque fruits un peu sûrettes. Tout une surprise!

Bottle - Pours dark brown/black, tan head.  Notes of sweet malt, roasted nuts, coffee, bitter hops.  Flavor is not as complex as I thought: coffee, roasted malt, bitter baking chocolate, dry aftertaste.... a hint of fruit.  Decent mouthfeel with a finish of hops.

Tap, Café Morshuis Albergen. Almost opague with a grey, lasting head. Roast bitter flavor with a pleasant raspberry fruitiness. Just a bit thin. Roast bitter aftertaste. Not a very rich Baltic porter but very tasty.

The color was a deep coffee black.  The head was dark tan, foamy, frothy, and thick.  The aroma resembled an imperial stout.  It consisted of chocolate tones and roastyness.  The flavor was soy sauce, waxy, bitter, coffee malt, and roasty.  The palate was smooth.  The finish was roasty.

Bottle, It poured an opaque black/brown hue with a tan head which had some lacing.  Aroma was very rich with a roasted mocha note.  Flavor was sweet with cocoa with a pleasant hop bite. Finish was almost syrupy.
12oz bottle. One of the best porters Ive had to date. Pours a black oil like color. Thick. Khaki colored head. Roasted malts abundance, coffee, chocolate. Delicious. Need more

Poured an oil black brew but lacked the viscosity. Had a thick brown creamy head. Resembled an ris (minus the thick head). The  nose showed soy sauce prominently, a slight sweetness, dark sugars. The flavor was dark roasty, coffee, sweet, soy sauce. The palate was thinner than an ris and more carbonated. The finish showed the 7% but just barely. I was thoroughly impressed with this Baltic Porter.
Pretty solid Baltic porter. Tastes a lot like the Baltika porter. Some off metallic notes. Very balanced and drinkable.

Black body, with a lasting tan head. Good lacing. Malty aroma, with liqourice, vanilla, and a surprisingly strong hop presence. A taste of roasted malts up front, proceeding into slightly sweet vanilla/liqourice territory, and finishing quite dry with decent hopbitterness and a lingering roasty finish. Medium/thick mouthfeel, slight carbonation. Enjoyable porter.

$5 bottle from Takanaya.  Pours pitch pitch black with no head.  Had some off butter smell, that went away after sitting a few minutes, and became a mild malt aroma.  The taste is very dry of roasted grains.
Pretty strong roasted malty aroma. Dark brown, nice foamy head. Stern, strong and roast flavor. Brisk, longlasting aftertaste. Very good Finnish beer, there arent so many of these (good beers).

Pours an oily black with a small light brown head.  Nice roasty chocolate aroma.  very big malt base as well.  Quite inviting smelling.  Nice body, very roasty with a good dose of chocolate as well.  Defintely get some coffee in there too, especially in the aftertaste.  Finish is nice and oily in the mouthfeel.  easy drinking but still thick and roasty.  Good porter.

Bottle. Chocolate-heavy nose with a tinge of smoke and some teriyaki. Black with a brown head. Flavor is chocolate with some lighter coffee undertones. Palate is unfortunately too thin, as is the failure of many an otherwise fine porter.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2012 An almost black beer with a medium and beautiful brown head. Aroma roasted, bread, liquirice and chocolate and lots of milky sourness. Taste is quite dry, roastiness, coffee, milky sourness and also lots of  nice, dry and herbal bitterness. Almost full bodied, nice and smooth to drink. Very good, rich, quite sour, balanced and enjoyable porter.

Sinebrychoff Porter
12 oz bottle
Moderate pour in an English pint
Bottled 2000, uncovered 2007

Poured black with a small light brown somewhat diminishing frothy head. To be expected from an old porter.

Smelt of strong vinous and burnt malt qualities, molasses, tar, raisins.

Taste was upfront strong bitter burnt grain, stale bread, cobwebs and tar and sweet raisins followed by a bitter burnt grain and coffee and sweet light molasses on a long finish.

Palate was medium bodied, oily, softly carbonated and moderately astringent.

Overall, I found that the 2 aged baltic porter Ive had recently smell and taste like musty basements.  This one has nice bold flavors and is very comfortable on the palate and the nose.
I need to try this fresh, but I am very happy with it as is.

33cl bottle - Pours black with a large tan head.  The aroma is of smoky, dark roasted malt.  The coffee accented flavor is darkly roasted and again I noticed some smokiness to it.  Moderate bitterness balances this porter well, though I thought it was just a little thin for the style.  Its good, but I didnt think it was as great as many seem to think.

bottle. the color of this beer is an impenetrable inky black. it pours with lovely beige head that is formed by tight tiny bubbles. complex aroma with layers of raisin, fig, molasses, port wine, wood, and sweet dusty malts. palate is creamy and satisfying without being to heavy and far from cloying. flavor is much like the nose, dark dried fruit, molasses, and a hint of port/ fortified red desert wine with some bitter chocolate and a most fantastic finish supplied by the near perfect amount of robust roasted malt and hop dryness.

Rating #1400.
(Part 1) Black in colour, tan coloured head, okay retention, some lacing.  The aroma has lots of chocolate, quite sweet, some liquorice, good amount of roast.  The flavour is of light chocolate, cold coffee, some anise, very light roast, some sweetness.  Thin mouthfeel, thin body, mild carbonation.  Finishes a little thin, very light bitterness, on the watery side.  7 years old and showing its age. 9/4/7/3/13
 330ml bottle from the <a
href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/new-york target=blank>Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, New York, opened on January 5, 2007
Vintage 2000.
(Part 2) Black in colour, beige coloured head, better retention, some lacing.  The aroma is very rich and sweet, lots of chocolate, some cake, cookies and toffee.  The flavour is again a bit light, good roasted bitterness, dark chocolate, coffee, sugary.  Watery thin mouthfeel, medium/light body, medium carbonation.  Finishes sweet and lingering.  Although a bit better then the 2000, this is still quite thin. 9/4/7/3/14
 330ml bottle from the <a
href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/new-york target=blank>Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, New York, opened on January 5, 2007
Vintage 1999.
(Part 3) Black in colour, beige coloured head - best head retention of the 3 vintages that I tried, some lacing.  The aroma is again quite rich, lots of chocolate sweetness, some roast.  The flavour is light, small roast, liquorice, dark chocolate.  The watery mouthfeel continues with this vintage, medium body, medium carbonation.  Finishes light, watery with just a small roasted maltiness.  The weakest of the bunch, lacking lots of body.  9/4/7/3/13
 330ml bottle from the <a
href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/new-york target=blank>Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, New York, opened on January 5, 2007
Vintage 1998.
All three of these smelled awesome, I would love to try a fresher sample.

Pours a crude oil black with a large, rocky, dark mocha head. Quite beautiful. The aroma is huge and complex; you can smell this beer a foot away from the glass. Heavy roasted malts, chocolate, toffee, raisins, plums and vanilla all delight the olfactory system. The only thing that kept this one from being a "10" is an odd, light soy sauce note in the background. The mouthfeel is fairly full-bodied, oily, moderately carbonated and lightly bitter at the finish. The flavor, while not quite the sensory overload that the nose presents, is quite satisfying.  Sweet roasted malts, plum, raisin, vanilla  and coffee notes conclude in a lightly dry finish. This is a remarkable beer.

totally unremarkable beer... when its cold. left it alone for a hour then came back to ....wow!  it really opens up at room temperature.  sweet malty molasses aroma. flavor is a complex mess of coffee, soy sauce, malt and dried figs. nice dry mildly bitter finish. lingering after taste of good black coffee.

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2008 The store I purchased this from (Greens on Buford Hwy) has this listed as being from 2003.

Appearance: Pours out a thick, opaque black body with a brown-colored head.
