Smell: Mmm! Wouldnt you like to know. Loads of sweet, luscious treats in the nose - dark chocolate, raisins, reduced-sodium soy sauce, molasses, coffee beans, and chimney soot.

Taste: While the aroma alluded to a sweeter taste, the flavor is mostly dry, with semi-sweet chocolate maltiness that comes across as being practically fudgelike. Some hints of coffee and licorice, too. A balanced, somewhat acidic bitterness makes for a quick finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-full body, with a dense, oily texture. Medium carbonation.

Drinkability: Well folks, its a good beer! You dont want to miss it. Its the chimney soot that does it.

Rated at the Pewaukee Tasting II 5/5/07.
2000 vintage courtesy of Murray.  
Appearance  Seriously black, tan head
Aroma: Deep prunes, plums, vinous, vanilla.
Flavor  Fruity, dark malts, very dry
Palate  medium bodied

11.2oz. Bottle
$2.96
Sams Downers Grove

Sinebrychoff Porter pours the deepest of browns. Mahogany highlights shine through only when held to the light. A 1 finger creamy tan head formed on the pour and left patchy lacing as it slowly receded. Leaves more lacing after each sip. Very nice looking beer.

The aroma is big and heavy. Molasses and dark fruits take center stage. The fruit in the form of figs and black cherries. Slightly doughy with a nice helping of bittersweet chocolate. Slight hint of frothed milk as it warms.

Flavor is identical to the aroma but the flavors are more subtle and blend seamlessly. Theres a very mild, soft metallic twang on the finish along with just a hint of coffee grounds. Good porter.

The mouthfeel is top notch on this beer. Its creamy and super smooth up front and gets frothy on the swallow. Zero hint of alcohol. 

The drinkability for such a big porter is very good. Subtle well balanced flavors and the absence of alcohol in flavor and heat make this beer an easy one to put away.

A good Baltic porter Ive been wanting to try for awhile now. Glad I finally did. Ill be picking up more of these in the future.

4/25/07

33 cl bottle. Sugary impy stout smell upon opening. Pours a thick brown under an inch-high brown foam. First impression I get in tasting is its hops, a rare thing for a porter. But there they are,  noble as Edward Tudor yet crude as Tom Canty. Backed up with plenty of molasses and fusels. It also reminds me of my very first Guinness all those years ago. Roasted graininess and wood burls, a little apricot and prune in the finish. Way too easy drinking for something this powerful!

Dark black-brown, opaque appearance, with a small but very dark brown head.  Absolutely beautiful.  Aroma of prunes and blackstrap molasses.  The flavor is rich and roasty with blackstrap molasses.  What a fine porter indeed!

Im not sure exactly why this is called Koff Porter.  Koff does not appear on the label at all, but not all things are meant to be understood.  What I do understand is that this brew is a fine beverage.  Pours dark and thick.  Big, creamy, dark brown head that refuses to relent.  Aroma of dark fruits and licorice, and the flavor more or less follows suit.  Definitely some roast in there, bit of chocolate.  Great long finish, creamy body, carbonation is perfect, just an all around delight to consume.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2009 Rerate 3-13-09. Bought circa October 2008.

Dark brown to black (again, of course). Rich medium sized frothy mocha head, leaving copious lacing as it settles. Oh the sweetest chocolate mousse and coconut milk aroma on this one, comparable to Pannepot of all things. The nose has seriously kicked it up a notch in the last few months. Any bitterness previously there has mellowed significantly and now only factors into the finish. I dont like my porters too light or too heavy; this one is just perfect, delivering all the goods. There is definitely something astoundingly Pannepotish in this one, just that instant of mellow chocolate mousse sweetness that hits you before melding into a light roasty bitterness. Perfect palate again. Overall, this is very, very good from an objective standpoint, but subjectively its still a little short of hitting that peak of deliciousness or complexity that takes a beer to the top. Besides that tiny criticism, this is highly recommended, buy several bottles and try them at different ages.

9 4 8 5 17 4.3

Orig. rating 5-13-07: Viscous, motor-oil black pour and a luscious chocolate mousse mocha-tan head. Roasty, chocolatey, turkish coffee aroma. Very full flavor, loads of malts, lots of roasty bitterness, also licorice. Oily body. A very excellent porter (probably because this is closer in style to my beloved imperial stouts), really glad I found this one. Salty finish.

7 5 8 5 17, 4.2

Peanut and oak aroma. Brownish black pour with a thin brown head, nice lacing. Roasted malt taste with some hops. Not overly sweet or tart. Smoke hops and vanilla finish. Middle of the road porter, but still a great beer.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2009 Keg (St. Urhos, Helsinki).
The Baltic Porter style is basically the Imperial Stout of old, and this is a perfect example. Heavy oily roasted aroma, but not enough to prepare you for the huge smack in the gob when you first taste it. Sweet, spicey, coffee, malty by the bucketload, with crisp bitter notes, and a sharpness from the carbonation that almost makes this 7.2%-er "refreshing". All of the above is well balanced I must add, which might be due to it being top-fermented.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2009 On tap at the Oluthoune Kaisla, Helsinki. Shiny jet black with a flat caramel head; a dense oily aroma; clean and cutting when tasted, slightly acidic, then aromatic coffee, then a fruit sweetness, then a delicately spicy aftertaste; leaving a definite "must have more" feeling in the mouth. Deceptively drinkable, little sign of the alcohol until a warm feeling kicks in as you get to the bottom of the glass.An exceptional beer, and a good choice for my 400th rating. [5/4/8/4/18]=3.9

11.2 fl oz bottle in the Birger, Hämeenlinna. Served in a very elegant 20cl glass, intense chocolate malt aroma; black body with a milk chocolate head; austere chocolate malt flavours to start, but developing a thick oily sweetness; leading to a well structured bitter sweet finish.

From mcbackus via trade.  Thank you again Matt!  This beer poured with a viscosity that I didnt expect.  Glugged out of the bottle into my pint glass looking every bit the part of a IS.  A tan and dark brown head sat atop the beer for a moment before giving way.  No real lacing.  The aroma was chocolate, roasted malt and some caramelized sugar.  The flavor was baking chocolate, roasted malt and a bit of cherry.  Medium bodied mouthfeel with a finish that lingered but not in an unpleasant way.  I think this beer was almost as good as the DR.  Not as complex in terms of aroma, but close.
The best beer a hat in Finland Black with small beige head Aroma of chocolate and caramel really balanced beer sweet finish.

Bottle:  Very attractive head with great lacing.  Chocolate aroma with a herbal qualities.  One of the better chocolate aromas Ive noted in a beer, that more than makes up for its lack of complexity.  In the mouth this beer opens with creamy sweetness and some cherry notes.  The rich, bitter chocolate flavors quickly mix and combine with the hops to dry this beer out considerably. The finish is a long and strong combination of all the preceding flavors.  The mouthfeel, body, and finish on this beer are all perfect more than makes up for the lack of deep complexity in flavor.  Excellent beer.
[bottled) Black with a rich head. Sweet, malty aroma with notes of dark berries. Well roasted flavour with notes of dark chocolate. Some alcohol in the finish. Quite sweet, but not too sweet.
11.2oz bottle. Pours black, with a hearty dark brown head. Sweet caramel aroma with some vinous notes. Sweet caramel balanced by dark chocolate flavors. Long, coffee finish. Beautiful!

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2008 Slightly fuller (almost oily), more well rounded beer than Fullers but with a malt character not quite as inspired--although it is well endowed with toasty, buttery maple/caramel flavor. The beers appearance is dark with a creamy head.  Hop flavor is well balanced and unobtrusive.  Carbonation is in the aftertaste more than hops.

Poured brown with a medium light brown head.  Aroma of soy sauce and roasted malt.  Flavor was roast, sweet, licorice, and a slightly bitter chocolate.  Some dark fruit.  Medium body, a little clingy on the palate.  A little strange for me.
Bottle.  Light aroma of smoked meat (kind of like beef jerky).  Smooth mouthfeel.  Flavor is like the smell; pretty smokey with a slightly sweet finish.

Pitch black beer with a creamy brown head.  Soft leathery aroma with strong notes of soy, dark chocolate, heavy roast and a lovely burnt sugar character.  The flavour is heavily roasty with lots of chewy, fruity sweetness.  Burnt toast, some dark malts, soy and a soft alcoholic flavour on the back.  Its a tasty Baltic porter, but the body seems a little lacking compared with some recent examples Ive had.

Poured from bottle with an average brown creamy,frothy head that was mostly diminishing with good lacing. Dark brown/black in color.  Had almost a wine like aroma.  Good smooth taste, however it did have a slight metallic flavor in the aftertaste.

Bottle. Pours a dark opaque brown with a one finger tan head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of licorice, caramel, roasted malt, and bitter sweet chocholate with a hint of dark friut and vanilla. Taste is the same with a good solid but not over done bitterness. This beer is very smooth and silky with the alcohol being very well hidden. A great example of a Baltic Porter

Aroma is of candied malts, coffee and bittersweet chocolate. Taste is more of this, with some hint of vanilla....all very well balanced. No burn whatsoever. A smooth, slick finish with a roasted finish. A really fantastic porter. Smooooooth.

2000 bottle.  When uncapping, there was no sign of carbonation initially, but after pouring, a small tan head emerged atop a dark brown body.  Smells of dark fruit, cloves, coffee, sugar, some warming alcohol, some oakiness, buttery  vanilla.  Tastes of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, nuts, caramel and some spices.  Mouthfeel is on par with a cognac and has a similar buttery finish.  This is a well-rounded beer that apparently ages very well.  Definitely worth the $1.19 I paid for the 12oz bottle!

bottle.  doesnt say koff anywhere on it.  anyways.  pour pure black with a very dark brown but reasonably large bubbled head.  which kinda made me expect an imperial stout (in the sense olfabrikken porter is a porter).  but this one actually is a porter.  heavily chocolate aroma.  really appetizing.  flavor is reasonably good.  definitely a porter, very hoppy.  surprisingly little body or malt backbone.  kinda bitter.

(Bottle from 2004) Pours black with a lasting light brown head. Light to medium roasted aroma with tones of caramel, chocolate and smoked sausage. Some hints of metal. Caramelly, light roasted flavour with a touch of smoke. Chocolate and coffee in the aftertaste. Notes of dark fruit both in the aroma and in the flavour. Rather sweet and lightly sour with a tiny bitterness. Medium body.

Wow!!! Pours like a dream. Big foamy chocolatey dark tan head, with some lace. Nose is incredibly aromatic - roasty, dark fruit, dark chocolate, burnt sugar ... enticing. Flavor is all of that and more. Only a hint of the power behind it. Luscious body. Ultra black opaque. A benchmark baltic porter. Having this one sitting at the tables by the big windows facing 4th Street in Bodega Brew Pub, La Crosse.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2008 <<RE-RATE 9/15/07>> 500 ml bottle at Waldo Pizza.  Appearance same as previous.  Aroma and taste contained a licorice / soy sweetness that I did not previously experience.  Still quite enjoyable, not the revelation of the previous experience.  9,5,8,4,17 (4.3) I will use this rating
<<ORIGINAL RATING 3/14/2007>> Bottle purchased at Oak Tree in New Jersy.  Pour is jet black, with a decent sized settling deep khaki head.  Aroma is quite present, malt, roast and just a touch of fruit sweetness (banana, maybe?).  Very much a porter taste, though the same sweetness is again present.  Roasted malt is the main flavor, with a nice lasting bitterness.  The body is not as big as I would have expected, but that actually made this more drinkable for me.  Great recommendation from the Oak Tree guys!  (9,5,8,4,18 - 4.4)

Bottle.  Pours black with a large tan head that disappears quickly.  Nice lacing.  Aroma is chocolate, roasted malts, with a floral hint.  Flavor is dark chocolate, molasses, and roasted malt.  Finish is dry and bitter.  This is my first time tasring this style and I enjoyed it a great deal.

Bottle. Very dark, burnt color. thick milk chocolate colored foam. Sweet aroma with syrup and malts. Tastes malts, smoke and chocolate. Not so roasted as appearance and aroma would hint. Feels like melted butter in mouth: oily and runny. Great beer!

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2007 The bottle I had was bought at Toppers in Helana Montana and it said Sinebrychoff. On a style I claim to know almost nothing about this was outstanding. Page 430 of Michael Jacksons Great Beer Guide and only 249 of his 500 Classic Brews to go.
definately would drink this again.  A very dark chocolate with a good balance taste

Bottle. Black pour with no head. Aroma held some vinous elements, chocolate, roasted malt and a tinge of funk. Doughy roasted malt in the flavor along with more vinous aspects as well. Full body with little to no carbonation which seems to suit the other components...bitter dry finish.

Bottle.  Pours very black with a brown head.  Sexy.  Aroma is malty as hell, dark fruits, light chocolate.  Taste is slightly watery, carbonated and chocolatey.  Good but I was expecting a little more.

Delilahs Vintage Beer Fest 2007 vintages 97 and 00. Pours dark brown with a beige head.  97 aroma is abundant very plumy chocolate, dark roast and dark fruit. 00 vintage lacks the dark fruit and plum and is more of a simple chocolate roast.  97 Chocolate roast flavors, tons of chocolate and dark fruit, damn tasty.  00 bitter bakers chocolate, but once again not leading to the complexities and fruit.  finishes dry.  At ten years this is a damn good beer.

Bottle thanks to Mcbackus. Poured a dark , thick body with a thin head, left a nice ring around the glass. Aroma is of chocolate malt, roasted malt and a small amount of hops. Flavor is bitter sweet with a sence of sugar to it. Light mouthfeel that is left kind of dry. This was smooth and the alcohol is undetected.

Pours thick black with a thick frothy brown head.  Chocolate, floral hops, molasses in the nose with a bit of alcohol sting.  Nice dark chocolate flavor with bits of dark fruit and roastiness at the end.  Im kind of getting an aluminum flavor right now which is dragging down this rating.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2007 Pours black with a small, full, dark tan head.  Aroma is very sweet.  Molasses, roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, and just the slightest hint of alcohol.  I could sit here and enjoy the aroma all night.  Body is full and silky smooth.  Flavor is Chocolate, molasses, roasted coffee, malt, and some dark fruit.  The roasted flavor really comes through in the end.  Also finishes nicely bittersweet.  A damn good porter.

I had this beer at Brigids in Philadelphia.  It poured an oily black, with a thick creamy biege head. Roasty aroma. Full and slick mouthfeel. Roasted chocolate, coffee, dark fruits, and hops on the tongue. Nice finish, with a lingering aftertaste. A truly great beer. An excellent example of its style.

Pours almost opaque black with a big dark creamy head that leaves a nice ring of lacing at the top of the glass.  Aroma is extremely roasty, with a little bit of alcohol coming through.  Taste is roasty and full with a nice roasty/bitter aftertaste.  Very good, but there are some cheaper examples I like just as much (the single 11.2 I found was 3.50, which is still not bad).

poured from a bottle which the bottle itself looked very old.  Jet black body with very little head.  The color of the head was orangish with a tint of tan.  The aroma again having a tough time with, I would say very sweet licourice (sp) and fruity.  Flavor got better thru the tasting, averall not bad for a kick of porter.

bottled. i tried a reasonably fresh bottle and a 3 year old bottle and certainly preferred the fresher one. aroma of fruit salad and coffee. quite yoghurty, slightly thin texture that resembled an aussie foreign stout, faint roasted flavours, pretty decent

This was bottled in 1997.  I dont think Ive had a beer nearly this old before.  Its delightful.  Cocoa aroma, delicious-looking head, blacker n a steers tookus.  Medium to thin body made up for by strong doppelbocky, Scotch-aley malt presence, with a combination of sweet and smoky finish.  Strong finish has flavor particles crisply dancing on the tongue.  (Medium-thin body actually works well on this - moving the palate score from 4 to 5.)  Ill gladly have another.  Worth seeking out.  Subsequent tastings might make this come down some, but right now its right up there.
I love the malt flavor of Weltenburger Asam-Back.  This is the closest Ive seen a beer come to that.  Scarily close.
I think I may come to really love this style.

The aroma has DEEPLY roasted malt, chocolate, brown sugar, and dark fruit. The appearance is DARK brow with a tan three finger head. The flavor has all the elements from the aroma plus some burnt wood. The palate is about right for a porter. This is good and would be better if it didnt have a burnt, astringent finish.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2016 Bottle, 7.2%. Black colour, dark brown head. No aroma to speak of. Sweet, roasted and creamy flavour. Medium bitterness. Creamy mouthfeel. 5 4 7 4 15

Bottle, 7.2%. Good bready aroma. Black colour. Big stable creamy light brown head. The flavour is bready with a good coffee note. Good dark bread and dark malty syrup notes. Semi-sweet, but balanced by a distinct bitterness. Creamy mouthfeel. 7 3 7 4 17

Pours with almost no head and black but if tilted it reveals a very dark birch beer color.  The nose reminds me of a good Pedro Ximenez, sweet, raisiny with  hints of coffee and chocolate bar.  Broad and ever so smooth on the palate.  Tastes like it smells with moderate hopping and the alcohol heft is well integrated.  Subtle compared to some imperial stouts.  Just right for what it is.
bottle: pours very black no light comes thru. nice tan head. aroma of dark fruits some malt and hops. the flavour is sweet with chocolate bliss and a nice bitter coffee finish. a fantastic porter.

Bottle. Porter IVB. Dark black color with a large good lacing light brown head. Aroma is light malty, hoppy, yeasty, fruit, notes off alcohol. Flavor is moderate sweet and moderate to heavy bitter with a long duration. Bitternes is coffe, chocolate bitternes. Body is medium to full, texture is oily. Good balance and complex taste.

Pours a dark dark brown, with a huge thick clump of tan foam. The head sticks around forever, leaving excellent lacing. Bold sweet aroma has a little bit of tart stone fruit (chokecherry?) and caramel. 

Flavors of smooth sweet caramel malt -roasted grain, a bit of coffee, some bitter dry chocolate, and more stone fruit. Mildly spicy hop bitterness. Aftertaste is complex with some alcohol like a sweet rum, more spicy hops, some floral hops, old coffee, and bitter roasted grain. Soft carbonation, full body.

2000 bottle.  Doesnt get much blacker than this; leaves a nice olive-brown film on the glass.  Aroma is chocolate covered cherry.  Flavors are a cascading waterfall of roasted malt, cranberry, and port wine.  A pleasant bitter coffee finish is left on the palate.  Lingering mouthfeel that reincarnates the flavors slowly and pleasantly.  Fantastic.  The alcohol sits quietly so the the flavors can take center stage.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: 11.2 oz botle from slob, who, as anyone who has traded with him knows, is the MAN. Jet black with a brown head. Big sweet nose, lots of dark molasses, raisin  and sticky malt. Flavor is more bitter than expected, but with an underlying syrupy sweetness - coffee, sweet malt, molasses, some chocolate and caramel. Thick body, smooth. Excellent.

11.2 oz bottle from World Of Beer. This is one of the darkest beers Ive seen. Its just absolutely black with a brown to light brown head. Full inviting aroma of molasses, dark fruit like dates and plums. The aroma is complex. I also get roasted malts, chocolate malts, and a bit of alcohol. From the fist two sips I get a metallic note that de-rails a nice tasting beer just as it was getting started. This off note does seem to subside as more beer is consumed. If this was a 22oz the second half of the beer would be flawless. So behind the initial metallic shavings I taste flavors that mirror the aroma with molasses, dates, plums, roasted malts and chocolate malts. Overall a nice tasting brew that leaves a rich roasted and chocolate malt taste behind.

Pours black with a soapy dark brown head.  The aroma has creamy milk chocolate and roasted malts, vanilla, malt balls and light alcohol.  Medium / thick body that is fairly smooth at first then it gets sharper with the carbonation on the finish.  The taste starts with roasted malt, cream and some sharp spice.  The finish adds some hop spice and tanginess.   Nicely done porter.

330 mL bottle.  Nice thick black pour with a moderately thick tan head.  Aroma has chocolate notes, a mild coffee aroma, a faint suggestion of smoke.  Palate is clean and smooth.  The taste is smooth as well, with roasted malt and oak flavors and a slightly bitter roast finish.  This is good, but I prefer Zyweic.

Courtesy of bditty187.

Pours a jet black that allows no light to seep through, with a thick two finger tan head that leaves behind a thick webbing of lace.

Smell; rich chocolate and coffee notes, with some roasted, almost smokey malts. Theres some dark fruits along with some hints of licorice.

Taste; the coffee and dark fruits really come out on the first few sips, along with a bit of licorice. Theres a strong roasted maltiness, with some touches of wood and a little alcohol. The chocolate character starts to come through as this gets warmer. Mouthfeel is light to medium bodied, and so drinkable I wish I had several more.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: this bottle had mettallic tatse.  nose roasty caramel.  had a somewhat ashy flavor to it along with caramel.  pretty smooth mouthfeel. ok

Bottle; pours a deep and thick black with a nice dark brown head that slowly diminishes down to a thin line; great lacing.  Sweetish aroma of roasted malts, molasses, chocolate, coffee and caramel.  Lots to offer and enjoy in the aroma.  Taste is more of the same with a roasty, thick and creamy palate and a gentle lingering aftertaste.  Very nice porter; recommended.

33 cl. Clearly this beer was meant to rescue me from my bottle shop import-spree doldrums tonight. Had no idea what I was getting when I randomly grabbed it. Pours ebony with a towering, 7-finger, sudsy tan head. Lots of chocolate on the nose, lots of nothing at all else, too. Restrained attack, with medium body, tangible carb, and present flavor. Clean, chocolatey, very dry, a bit chalky mid-palate. Lingering, very chalky finish. I gotta get over my chalk hangup cause clearly its not a niche phenomenon.
Bottle shared by mikemac at the oak cafe. Poured w/ a big brown head and very black appearance. Aroma was a little chocolatey. Flavor was pretty sweet with some chocolate in the finish.

Bottle. A well lagered one from 1999, opened at Christmas 2005. Pitch black colour, small mahogny head. Sweet caramellic and roasty aroma with alc. and bitter chocolate. Smooth, roasty flavour with bitter chocolate, coffee, raisins and plums and alcohol. Long aftertaste. It really pays off to let some of the dark strong brews lager for some years, hidden away cool and dark.
Mineral, caramel, and yeasty nose.  Pours a thin brown head with slight lacing.  A dry, ashy, malt-husky flavor.  Not a bad porter by any means.
Spledid porter from the Findlads biggest brewery. Propably the best store-sold porter available in Finland.

Very dark and very rich with cocoa. the nose overwhelm the smells of dark roasted malts and caramel.  Even though it has high Alcoholic content, it does seem to hit me as other strong beer. perfect for a night cap

Pours black with a thick creamy/frothy light brown head. Strong sweet aroma of dark fruit, cognac, and light caramel. Flavor is more subdued, light bakers chocolate, some roasty black coffee, very light hints of dark fruit, and a nice bitternss on the finish. Palate is meduim with some roasty malts and mild bitterness lingering. Pretty solid/balanced brew, but I expected more from the powerful aroma.

Bottle. Pours black with a significant brown head. Nice molasses and roasty malt aroma. Creamy medium body with light carbonation. More molasses in the taste along with chocolate and coffee. A touch of espresso and pine in the exit that builds a bit as I get closer to the bottom of the glass.

1999 vintage I wish I could say I had the years of knowledge, the due diligence, the foresight, the experience, and capacity to have personally saved a bottle of this beer for 7 years.  But it would be a lie, maybe in 7 years from now I will be able to say that.  This bottle was bought at a special vintage event and it should have been kept relatively well.  It was fridged for 48 hours and held at room temperature for about 20 minutes.  Popped with a small hiss and pours with just the smallest brown lacing.  Aroma is on the mild side of being present and mainly a charred malt.  Taste is a bit better with some chocolate and a nice dry roastiness in the aftertaste.  Body is lighter than I like (I usually find this to be the problem with the Baltic, Baltic Porters).  A bit of bitterness at the end as well. This has lost a lot of the characteristics I enjoy in a fresh Koff, which I really enjoy.  So I guess in the end  I will never get to say that I have a saved a Koff Porter for 7 years.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: i can see why baltic porters are getting so popular, this is a solid beer.  it has a nice roasted malt flavor with some chocolate and fruitiness.  i like the mouth feel, its almost creamy...  excellent buy at $2.50 a bottle.

Poured a deep mohagony to black fluffy brown head. A sweet and grass like aroma was present with a touch of roast malt. Flavor was sweet with noticable notes of molases and honey backed up by dark fruit..

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2007 Bottle shared by mikemac: Black with a dark tan head. Aroma of dark fruits, some coffee, and a bit of chocolate. Flavor, molassas, prunes, coffee. Pretty solid. Picked up a 1998 bottle that I cant wait to try.

Re-rate: 1998 vintage: Black with a small tan head. Aroma, some fruits, chocolate, and a hint of soy. Flavor, sweet chocolaty, some coffee, a bit of soy again, but nothing offensive. It held up pretty damn well.

Vintage 2000 - Pours pitch black with a fully receding mocha head. Aroma of rum, phenolic spice, fruity chocolate. Taste is spicy, chocolatey, phenolic.
Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with soft carbonation. Very tasty. A bit thin bodied for a porter, but I will buy this again.
Roasted malt aroma, but not really all that strong of an aroma.  Black with a medium brown head.  The palate is full.  Taste is mostly bitter chocolate and roasted malt.

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2007 20030bottle.  Dark, dark brown and opaque in color with a very full and creamy,almost fluffy, head that lasts with a dark beige color and minimal lacing; head looks like a rootbeer float.  Nose is a little weak but not unpleasant; notes of butter and chocolate with some fruitiness and a rootbeer-like smell.  Taste is curious, not like other strong, dark ales; dark chocolate, burnt toast, dark cocoa, a curius sour note, some lightly roasted coffee notes, and a moderate bitterness.  Palate is medium, soft, and creamy, almost dry.  Finishes with earthy hops, burnt chocolate, and mostly dry.  Some excellent qualities but some abstract ones as well. Very easy drinking and a little scary at 7.2%.
Bottle. On the label it said Sinebrychoff, not Koff. Pours black with thick dark, brown head. Roasted, Coffee and chocolate. Not too sweet, a nice porter.
Aroma is of sweet milk chocolate.Pours dark black with huge tan head.Has a nice balance of chocolate and hops.Medium to thin mouthfeel with some noticable hops in the finish.

Pours opaque black with thick dark, brown head. The aroma is almost vinous - malts and chocolate, molasses and dark fruit. The flavor starts with lots of bitter cocoa and burnt toast. The subtle sweetness of the malts transition to more chocolate and some hop flavor. The finish has some hops and some fruit - and lots of chocolate. The mouthfeel is quite thick and full-bodied - but smooth and creamy thanks to the carbonation.
Winter and cold weather are the friends of this dark and tasteful beer.  Try this 50/50 Koff porter/light lager(any) and you will find something very special enjoyable year-round.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2007 Bottle 0.33 l. Opaque black with nice brown lacy head, looks fabulous. Fresh milk chocolate nose. Flavor is initially roasty bitter and sour, but reveals creamy coffee and sweet chocolate, and little fruitiness. A tad watery body, sour and easy drink. Yet good.

Bottled in 2000:  Pours an opaque black color with a brown head.  Sweet and roased malts with notes of coffee.  Bitter roasted malts with some coffe and a long sweet malt finish.  Medium mouth feel.  Good Porter.
Sourness, dark black with a little head, some coffee, soot, tar, a little watery, some bitterness, big minus on the smell

Bottle.  Molasses, dark brown coloring.  No head, save for an enticing brownish bubble ring around the glass.  Chocolate, malty, almost fudge-like to the tongue offset by carbonation.  Quick finish.  Quite pleasurable for a porter.
UPDATED: MAY 30, 2008 2000.  pitch black under a very dark brown head.  extremely dark aroma of chocolate.  flavor is the same.  very dark and chocolatey.  very good stuff.

This pours very dark black, with a foamy, brown head.  Scent is malty with molasses, and a bit of woodiness.  The beer smells sweet, but the flavor is predominantly dry.  Theres plenty of malt flavor, but the hops (I cant place them) cover over most of the sweetness.  The flavor is also slightly metallic.  Finish is also dry, and the aftertaste borders on bitter.  The palate is my favorite part of this beer -- like silk, even at room temperature.  This beer is very, very tasty.  Ive had it several times, and im always impressed.

330 ml bottle. Pitch black colour and a really tall brown creamy egg-white head. A little yeasty. Crisp flour-like roasted chocolate aroma. Smooth rounded chocolate flavours. Rounded and mellow from debittered malts. Dark chocolate and a little coffee. Quite bitter finish that lasts for quite some time.
Bottled. Pours black coloured with a small head. Roasted and slightly fruity sour. Notes ofcoffe and has a slightly hoppy finish.

Big, dark brown lasting head over opaque black body. Sweetish, roasty aroma with notes of bitterness. Rounded. Smooth, rounded roasty and burnt malt taste with coffeeish, oily, chocolatey notes. Wide-bodied, smooth, oily, rounded. Bitter, burnt toast aftertaste. Excellent! A beautiful porter. (0.33l bottle.)
A decent porter with a nice warming 7.2% abv. A great winter night fireside beer.

Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus, and also one sampled with The Mad Indian. Both Bottles from 2000 (Sinebrychoff). Pours dark with a brown head. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, and fruit. The flavor is much the same, with certain qualities becoming more dominant as it warms. Great beer.

Bottle. Pours near black with an enormous, slowly dissipating red-tinged tan head. Aroma of soy sauce (weird...), prunes, chocolate, and caramel... very sweet overall. Taste is quite smoky and malty and it finishes dry with a bit of bitterness. Loses most of the sweetness thats in the aroma, which I wish it didnt. Seems like its missing something. Solid but not quite great.
Draught. Pours pitch-black with brown head. Sweet and dry aroma. Full-bodied but slightly metallic. Dry mouthfeel.

bottle from whole foods.  pours an opaque black, with carbonation that needs coaxing out.  aroma is sweet caramel malts, roast...actualy quite like coffee.  full bodied.  flavor is tremendous: hot chocolate, caramel candies, little bits of toast, and a just slightly sweet finish.  no noticable hops, but the finish is drier than you would expect.  a tremendous porter.

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2007 Bottle, molasses and malty aromas.  Dark brown with a milk chocolate head.  Light metallic tinge in the flavor.  Roasted malty flavor with slight bitter finish.  Tastes better the more you drink.  Light chocolate, perhaps coffee notes.  Dry palate with light bitter finish.  Good.

Pours a beautiful black with a huge, solid, dark brown head. Aroma is fruity, soy sauce, and reminiscent of some weirder vegetables: leeks and string beans, perhaps. Flavor is similar, fruitier, some roastiness in the finish, still pretty dry, but round in weird way. Im not really sure what to make of this thing.

Pours a thick chocolate black with a nice tan head.  Aroma has notes of coffee, chocolate, and dark fruit.  Flavor is a medley of roasted coffee, dark chocolate, dark fruit, and a nice alcohol warming sensation.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2006 Thanks to beered_one for this great brew. Hands down the best porter I have ever had. (bottled in 2000) Pours black smells of chocolate and coffee. Incredible smooth(not overly sweet) chocolate flavor that just gets better as the beer warms up. Full body ,great after taste. INCREDIBLE!
Pitch black beer, deep rich color.  After taste reminds me of soy sause, but in a good way.  A good, solid porter for anyone to try.
pours jet black with a nice side tan head that has good lacing. Smoky roasted and nutty aroma. Smokey coffee and chocolate flavors. Creamy body with a slight bitter aftertase.

Pours a pitch-black chocolate color with brown edges; attractive head formation and good lacing.  The aroma shows rum raisins, some dark chocolate.  Definite vanilla notes, raisins, milk chocolate, roasted malt character, with some smoke and a slightly charred taste on the finish (all well-integrated).  A very tasty, very drinkable porter.

[Sampled at RGESG 2006]
Black with a brown head.
Sweet fruitiness in the aroma.
Fullbodied with loadds of maltiness.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2006 Bottle sampled with Beerded_one (bottled in 2000). Pours Dark with a one finger thick cola colored head. Aroma of roast, coffee, chocolate, and caramel. The flavor is silky smooth, roast, chocolate, coffee, caramel, slight fruit, sweet with a tiny bitter finish. Good body, Great brew.

Labled as a Sinebrychoff Porter IV, vintage 1997.  One of the last few we had at Bottleworks.  Pours a dark black with a foamy beige tanned head that sticks around.  The aroma gives a blast of dark roasted malts, vanillad coffee, and dark fruits.  The flavor starts off quite smooth and foamy like the head with a sweet touch of fruit that quickly bounces into a dark and roasted coffee espresso note with a bit of a dark cocoa powder and dark molasses backing to it.  From there a gently done bitter hop note takes over into the finish which lingers for a bit.  Everything about this brew is dark, dark, dark.  Has held up quite well for being 9 years old!!  Not much, if any hint of alcohol, though Im sure when it was fresh in 1997 you could probably taste it.  Overall, very impressive!
UPDATED: OCT 25, 2008 Bottle. The beer is completely black with a dark-brown foam. Aroma of sugar, liqurice and melas. This tastes sweet bith the hops impart a strong bitter finish.

"Thanks to eagle for this one. 2000. What a beer poured almost black with tan head. Aroma was of roasted, dark fruits. Flavor was of chocolate dark fruits, coffee. SOme hops in the aftertaste. Solid beer."

Bottle at RBESG 2006.
Black coloured with a huge beige head.
Roasted aroma of caramel, dried fruits and liquorice.
Roasted flavour of liquorice, dried fruits and caramel.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2006 12 oz bottle from Liquid Solutions. Large dense tan head. Chocolate, mocha, vanilla, caramel aroma. Tastes like it smells with a dry espresso finish. Full bodies, thick and chewy mouthfeel. Bittersweet cocoa aftertaste. Some sourness in the hoppy roasted malt finish. Quite tastey.

Actually had this as a Sinebrychoff Porter IV, bottled in 1997. Poured to a jet black, with medium tan head and very good lacing. Initial aroma of malty toffee, with hints of chocolate. As beer warmed, alcohol also made its presence known in the aroma. This beer is fdefinitely better as it warms at mid-glass. Finish at first is metallic, but later on is smooth and rich. I hope I can find another of this kind and age.
Palonen bought me this bottle.  Pours a dark brown.  Aroma of roasted malt, slight alcohol.  This is the perfect specimen of the porter style.
Bottle. Pours a nice thick dark brown almost black with a two finger tan head. Aroma of expresso and malt. Taste of coffee and caramel with a hint of smoke. A nice porter.

Nice pour - extremely dark and opaque with a fluffy orangey-brown head that looks just like a chocolate mousse. 

Initial aroma is of roasted coffee beans, but any burnt aspects dissipate. Theres some sweetness in the nose, maybe toffee, and a mild floweriness from hops.

The beer is smooth, thick, and slightly oily on the palate. No roasted flavors like you might expect from an American version, but thats no fault. Chocolate takes its turn on the tongue and the beer features a very pleasant drying bitterness. The high alcohol is almost completely masked. This is a very fine beer. No gimmicks, just quality.

very, very dark pour with an orangey, tan head which settles nicely to delicate lace.  aroma was mild chocolate and some citrus hops.  flavor had many layers: coffee, raisins, molasses, dark malts, vanilla, smoke, but chocolate dominates.  palate is smooth and creamy.  at just $2.19 per bottle, this was my good buy of the week!
Beautiful beer here, full roasted aroma as well.  Taste falls a bit flat for me, overly crisp and charred, not complex.  Good stuff nonetheless, just not world class.

Bottled. Opaque black color with diminishing dark brown head. Strongly burnt, salty and vinous aroma with rye, black currants, toffee and rum. Strongly burnt and charred flavor, fairly bitter also. The finish is long, charred and smoky with bitter chocolade notes. Fairly carbonated. Very uncompromising stout with black malt overload.
Pours very dark, with a thin tan head.  Rich thick body, with a balance of hops and malt.  Heavy chocolate and coffee flavor.  Clean finish
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text:
33 cl bottle .
very dark brown almost totally black beer with a tan head , with some purplish tinges..looks great.
Mostly toasted malty aromas , but some funky fruitiness there too.
Good flavours of figs,raisins, 70% cocao Dark chocolate and  actually quite a hop presence compared to others in this category.
Pretty exciting on the tongue..though the carbonation is per haps a touch to much.
Not the Best Baltic but probably the most authentic I have had..good but not great.

nice three finger medium brown head. unexpected grapes and grape juice in the nose accompanied by roasted malt. flavor is coffee and a touch of caramel with more lightly sour grapes, and some anise. a little thin in body and finishes a touch metallic.

Very dark, almost black beer with a nice and creamy dark beige to brown head. Aroma is suggesting a sweetness in the taste, it has a well hidden sour accent and lots of coffee hints with a touch of roasted malts. Taste is dryer than expected and the beer leaves a slight midicinal touch in the taste. It is faintly herbal, malty and spicey. In the afthertaste you can notice accents of dry honey, grass and hops. Nice beer with good ballace, but lacs that extra touch to be great.

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2006 Originally very dark head, gradually clearing out to yellow brown, dense & creamy; very dark, nearly black beer with some burgundy highlights. Coffee nose, but caramelly at the same time, quite sweet. Taste is fully roasted, scorched coffeebeans or breadcrust, sweetness just a faraway cry. After some time, a typical sourness from roasted barley appears, however restrained. Bit aggressive burning, and not at all full-bodied, thin for a 7.2 ABV beer. In the aftertaste a flavour as from brown sugar, but without any sweetness. OK, but nothing more.  Thanks to lachesis for sharing this one.

bottle.   Very dark brown, almost black, with a long lasting tan head.  Aroma is chocolate, caramel, dark malts with some dark fruit.  Taste is the same and sweet up front, some grain, and a roasty, and slightly astringent finish.

Sampled from bottle.  Pours opaque blackened-brown with a thick, mountainous tan head.  Aroma is cocoa, molasses and toasted bread.  Flavor is slightly bitter with a bit of cocoa in the finish.  Otehrwise, quite clean.  Incredibly easy to drink for a 7.2% beer.  Full body and well-carbonated, but not gassy.  The best Baltic Porter Ive ever had.

Bottle, The Foodery in Philadelphia. Pours jet black with a tan foamy head. Little lacing, an extremely nice look. Has an aroma of espresso and coffee, maybe raisens and some chocolate. Has a charcoal taste at first which milds out with the roasted malt flavor. A nice vanilla finish which balanced the beer into different flavors. A sweet porter that goes down nicely even as I had it in the summer heat. I look forward to this again.

Pours black with a large, dark head. Excellent aroma of toffee, sweet maple, chocolate and...what the hell is that?...blueberry, I believe--a sweet blueberry not unlike the smell of Boo-Berry cereal. It works with the other aromas very well. Very nice toasted malt flavor with a lightly hoppy and alcoholic finish. Im convinced that when Porters stay out of the realm of Stouts they are some of the best beers in the world. This one is nice and thin, with no overly-roasted flavors, but big enough to be (very) interesting. I could drink this all day. Incredible.

Bottled in 2000.  Poured black with ruby highlights at the edges.  Low in carbonation had to high pour to get a head.  Aromas are fantastic, a deep rich coffee sweeteded with molasses, vanilla, and maple syrup.  Some port character shine through with some fruit and winey notes.  Flavor is enjoyable but disappointing after the aroma.  A large amount of residual sweetness, though is somehow thin and slightly watery.

Bottle. Poured a thick black color with a creamy, chocolate milk like, brown head that left light lacing. The aroma is sweet malts, licorice and a nutty hint. The flavor found coffee and fruits upfront with a roast and chocolate after taste. Medium to full body that is sweet throughout.
Bottled. Black in colour. Rich brownhead, lacings. The aroma is sweet with burnt malt and licorice. The flavour is malty, burnt malt that is. There is a dry and bitterlike aftertaste.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2007 Vintage 2000. A beauty, a darned beauty. Dark brown, blackish color, very nice head for this old of a beer at these alcohol levels. Aroma was of dried dark fruits, some licorice, light roasted tones. The flavor was complex, although less "rich" than I was expecting, very well attenuated, even somewhat dry. Light coffee, some chocolate, licorice, dried fruits, and some roasted accents. Nice hop touch to the finish, again, a dryness that kept this from feeling "thick," deceptively thin. Lingering bitterness along with a grainy mouthfeel, more paralleled with the schwarzbier style (like Kostritzer) than the other top Baltics Ive had. A nice beer. Re-rate, February 07: Consistent experience, tan to chocolate colored head, perhaps a touch more hops noticeable in the finish, a fresher vintage, although I couldnt tell what year it was by looking at the bottle. Very nice.

Black, darken, impenetrable and elegant aspect. Dark nut color, creamy and adherent head. Complex and balanced scent: notes of smoke, embers, roast wood and malt. Pungent but velvety taste, much soft and without excessive alcoholic notes. Pleasant bitter with smoke notes that remember burned wood and ash. A lot balanced, much soft and rich of smells.
Thanks to mabjork for this great beer.

Bottled in 1997, bottle #3536. WOW! Now THIS is a nose! Big rich nose full of raisin, whisky, butter, and malt sweetness. Body is nearly opaque with a foamy film of bubbles. Taste-grape, medium bitterness, fig, light soy, very little chocolate and coffee, a good wallop of aroma hops on the tongue, cola, and an overall flatness. Very well done and well made. As I said with the FD gonzo, beers like this could easily make my favorite style Baltic Porters!
Flavor was a blend of coffee, malt, chocolates, hoppiness, and fruits.  Aroma was mostly fruit and sweetness, doesnt have the same depth that the taste does.  A solid porter for sure.

Pours black with huge brown head, medium length with beautiful laces; 1 dimensional, huge nose, lacks complexity and depth: fresh fruity, a bit green together with a little molasses; metallic, full but also quite acidy body; into a very short metallic, sugary finish with some acidy bitterness. By the way, I have never seen this much yeast in the bottom of a beer before in my life, I guess that was the best experience with this beer.

From the bottle.

Pours a relatively dark black with a big fluffy tan head. The aroma is roasted malt, a bit of agar, and some sweaty socks. The flavor is dark-roasted grain, bits of sweetness, hints of fruit, with a decent bitter finish that is too heavy on the burnt coffee. The mouthfeel is enjoyable, but slightly thin for the ABV.

This is a nice strong porter, but drinking it head-to-head against the exceptional Dark Horse Reserve Black Bier, it just doesnt measure up in aroma, flavor, or mouthfeel. It has nothing like the flavor complexity of the Dark Horse, and the palate comes off on the thin side.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2006 (Bottle BB 02/07/07) Roasted malty, coffee-like and chocolaty aroma. Black colour and large, brownish, slightly lasting head with good lacing. Roasted malty, very bitter, coffee-like, licorice-like flavour of long duration. Softly carbonated, slightly astringent, dry and full-bodied palate. Even though some Finnish micro brews are finally starting to approach the quality of Sinebrychoff Porter, it is still the flagship of Finnish beers! An excellent brew! 31/08/06 (original rating was 8/5/8/5/16)

Bottle purchased at Friar Tuck in Savoy, IL. Pours a brown-black with a deep brown hue, although the carbonation is exessive. On the nose, theres plenty of chocolate and a hint of unpleasant cardboard. On the palate, lots of chocolate and sugar, and then a strong bitter finish. This sudden contrast of sweetness and hops was unnerving. I found this beer analagous to an attractive cousin of the opposite sex; the juxtaposition is always unsettling.

330 ml bottle thanks to Kramer17801.  Very dark pour with minimal head.  Not much left after a few minutes.  Aromas were heavy chocolate and roastiness and fresh baked bread.    Flavor is sweet at first with a tight carbonation on the tip of the tongue.  Coffee flavors are next.  Some hoppy bitterings, and a rather subtle dustiness that just reminds you that this is a porter after all.  Very good.
very heavy chocolate, a strong taste to it nice hops malty aftertaste is like a cheap thrill it will give any porter fan a happy dick
black with a creamy head.  huge chocolate aroma, this brew is rich and tasty.
UPDATED: NOV 14, 2007 Some vanilla and molasses.  Pours a dark brown with a chocolaty head.  One of my favorite porters.

Pours a very nice deep brown with a thin, milk chocolate colored head. Aroma is roasted coffee and chocolate malted milk balls. Tastes a bit smoked, with milk chocolate, and strong brewed coffee. Nice full mouthfeel and ends a tad bitter. I really like this one. A good find!

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2006 Bottle/Ludwigs.  Nice rootbeer tufty lightbrown head head on mahogany almost black beer.  Rum raisin wood chocolate roasty bitter chocowood... rummy log cabin...dark fruit...perty good.
Re-rate: bottle from olivers.  Wasnt so great; lagery corn aroma, blackbread, corny can flavors, burn molasses.  May have been old, the imports at Olivers have to be chosen carefully, they dont seem to have good turnover.  Not altering the numerical rating much as a result of skepticism that this is the beers fault.
Roasted nose, jet black color, tan spongy head. Licorice tastes, bitter chocolate bitter. Coffee end - fairly bitter. Medium body. Crisp texture, but smooth as well. Bold porter. Nice one.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2008 I just smiled when I pour this one. Looked like iodine and the froth rose like a balloon filled with chocolate ice cream. Hung there all rocky w/ a lingering fluffy lace. Beautiful! Aromas of sweet roasted malt. Medium nectar w/ mild carbonation creating a silky texture. A strong roast component kicks in pushing flavors of dark cocoa, coffee, leather. A mellow hop factors in on the end that lends a nice balanced bitterness to it.  The finish s bittered well w/ lingering charcoal. Not sweet at all ending w/ a slight lactose souring. .

bottle, from Downeast Bev. Co. pours balck, with one of the darkest heads ive seen. just beautiful. aroma is of bannana and chocalate with some mocha.  strong burnt malt flavor, with bitter chocolate. hints of vannila maybe some caramel too. nice hint of hops in the finnish gives it some bite. leaves a coffee aftertaste on the palate. well balanced. smooth and  creamy. not a hint of alcohol. definatly one of the best porters ive tried.

damn. Probably the darkest pour Ive ever witnessed. Thick as oil she was, with a head of dark mocha walking 15 miles upwards. Cascades beautifully. Couldnt really pick a solid nose off this. Didnt have that offsetting tangent you sometimes get with porters. Taste....surprising indeed. Struck me as if I had swallowed the contents of an ashtray at the New Yorker (No one at the New Yorker has anuses.). Strong dark chocolates flow around a waff of cigar smoke while sitting in my favourite smoking jacket. Pitty it was brewed well after Washingtons time, im sure he would have given the thumbs up.

Yummie - thanks a lot Juha! Opaque colored with a nice huge hazelnut brown head on top that lastes long. Clay and band aid, also roasted malt nose. Smooth - bitter, raosted malt taste that lasts long. Nice one!

330mL bottle found on discount beer rack presumably because it is past date - best by date indicates June 03. Pours with gorgeous dark tan tight large head leaving all kinds of lace. More or less completely opaque black color. Strong chocolate and coffee and dark malt aroma. Fantastic full malt/chocolate flavor with fairly clean roasted finish. Love this beer. And to think - all Id had of Finland before was Lapin Kulta and I thought that was a decent pilsener....

(33 cl bottle via trade with <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=1 target=blank>beeryum, thanks Dave!) Pours almost as black as coal (actually very, very dark brown) with a small tan head. Aroma has sweet molasses, prunes, raisins, caramel. Fine sloppy lacing. Mouthfeel smooth, a touch prickly in finish. Flavor is good, but not as multi-dimensional as aroma. Somewhat port-like, so has kind of a grape and coffee-like taste with a hint of plum in finish. Finish is also fairly bitter and a little dry. Good.

From a 11.2 oz. short brown bottle with no bottled/freshness date. Made a very good appearance, poured a syrupy opaque black with a nice sized sticky tan head that slowly settled into a thin bubbly lacing, moderate carbonation. Had a dark ripe fruity and burnt chocolate nose with a slight woodiness. A slick, semi-creamy, textured full bodied mouth feel, good drinkability. A rich chocolate/coffee malt taste, a dark fruitiness, a mellow alcohol warmth in the palate and a sweet fruity and dark chocolate finish.
I have been wanting to try this porter since coming across it in Michael Jacksons "Great Beer Guide" (p.430, 2000 edition). An excellent Baltic Porter, delicious tasting, well worth seeking out.

12 oz bottle, 2001 or 2002 vintage.  Pours an opaque black body under a small wispy covering of dark brown head.  Aroma is large and complex, with chocolate pudding, vanills, soy, alcohol, carmalized dark fruits, and cooked whole wheat pasta.  Flavor is roasty with a caramel overtone.  Hints of burnt coffee, chalk, plums, raisins, and dates.  Finish is dry and lingers quite a while.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied with moderate, very fine bubbled carbonation.  Slightly oily in texture on the finish.  Overall, almost as good as I remember it, but I think that I enjoyed it a bit more about a year ago when I last had a bottle from this batch.

(03.18.06) 11.2 oz brown  bottle purchased from DiCarlos, Mundelein, IL. 7.2% ABV. Bottle labeled as best before 6/23/03. Pours opaque brown black with giant long lasting head. No discernable carbonation. Soy sauce and prunes in the nose. Full bodied with light malt sweetness and prune/roasted malt flavors. Vinous quality, reminiscent of port wine. Finishes with roasted coffee and burnt malt aftertaste. Smooth in the mouth.  Though the port wine characteristic is somewhat overpowering,  this is a very good drinkable porter.

330ml bottle poured a nearly opaque reddiish black wiyh a long lasting brown head. Aromas of dark chocolate, some vinous notes, a bit of coffee and a hint of smoke. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of roasted malt, bitter chocolate, and a hint of smoke with a smooth, lingering bittersweet finish.
Dark black color with a medium creamy brown head that mostly diminishes. Chocolate and roasted malt aroma. Sweet chocolate flavor with a hint of bitterness.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2008 Bottle. 0,33l. Completely black with a delicate creamy brown head. Filigrees on the glass. Smell of chocolate. Roastedness dominates in the aroma - gradually tranformed into a cascade of other tastes. Chocolate again - and then some fruits. A lasting sweet fin(n)ish. Very good. KI=8

This one suffered being in comparison to the Olfabrikken, which we sampled directly before. A big sweet treacle aroma. Doesnt seem to have the depth of flavour that the abv should command - its fairly bland and a bit watery. Good beer, but I expected more from this.

Koff Porter smalls of raisins ands smoke, which are also present in the full flavour. Prunes, toasted grain,, very complex, almost salty. A dry, slightly sour finish. Pitch black with a nice head the color of milk chocolate. 7,2% alcohol adds warmth. A great beer.

Pours black as night with a tan head.  Aroma is very roasty.  Flavor is of roasted malt, coffee and chocolate.  There is quite a bit of hop bitterness present.  Mouthfeel is nice and full. Finish is smooth.  A good Porter

Bottle: Poured a pitch-black color porter with a medium dark creamy had with very good retention. Aroma of chocolate is omnipresent with a nice touch of bitterness. Body is full and has a nice creamy texture that is very enjoyable. Taste is also dominated by the chocolate malt with nice light bitter ending. Very nice example for the style and probably even better then Okocim.

330ml bottle from Alko in Finland. Enjoyed for nearly an hour late on a Friday afternoon in silent surroundings. Almost black, mocha-like, on colour. Brownish head. Strong malty aroma. Creamy and full bodied. Flavours of espresso coffee and dark chocolate. Bittersweet finish. A great Porter-version (03.03.2006).

bottle. Quite opaque black brew with a dense tan head. The aroma is of soy sauce, instant coffee, thin chocolate. Much soy sauch in flavor with burned bark, but this gives way to a nuttier and sweeter finish. Great depth for the style.
Bottle.  Deep black beer with a strong brown head.  The aroma is malty and coffee, and the flavour is deeply dry espresso coffee.  Overall a good beer.

BEUTIFUL full brown head. Honestly one of the best heads I have seen. Sweet chocolate aroma. Flavor is delicious, wonder chocolate and caramel flavors. This beer would be great as a desset. This is an absolutly wonderful stout.  Very drinkable and sweet.

Deep black with a big, lasting tan head. Mild chocolate aroma, with some nice coffee and hop notes. Flavour is a combination of grapes, roast coffee and chocolate. A little sweet, with some burnt notes as it finishes with a nice bitterness.  Medium bodied.

Super dark, nearly opaque with a slowly receding brown head that leaves tons of lace.  The taste is rich roasted chocolate with a malty sweetness in the background with an alcohol warmth.  Heavy, lightly carbonated mouthfeel.  An excellent porter, one that I would definitely try again!

Aroma:strong chocolate aroma.....
Appearance:Dark,brown head...
Flavor:strong chocolate flavor,rosted malt,alcohol....

Oily in consistency and color. Black! Beautiful cappucino-like brown foam. My nose picks up chocolate, malts and some hops. Malty flavor, licourice and coffee. Fizzy and a bit sticky palate. An extra point for being from Finland!astringent, astringent,
Pours deep black into a shaker.  Malt and fruit notes, maybe some chocolate.  Nice mocha-colored head with good lacing. Lightly sweet and a little smoky. Slick with a long smoky finish.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2006 Got the pleasure of drinking a bottle of this that was aged 12 years.  Poured a black color with a medium tan head.  Aroma was of fruit (cherries maybe) malts, and chocolate.  Taste was the same, a little sweet but not too much.  Very good, I highly recommend keeping a bottle of it in a cellar and forgetting about it.

Bottle.  Poured a very deep brown with garnet highlights... tall initial mocha head receded to a 1/4" layer, and quite a bit of lacing followed it down.  Aroma was chock fulla roasty dark malts... bakers chocolate and coffee among other stuff.  Also found some woody/leafy hoppage and tannins.  Flavor was also malt-centric with a nice balance between the dry chocolate, coffee, caramel, and floral hops.  Not much more than a medium body to it, but the flavors flowed extremely well.  Dry chocolate and woody bitterness at the finish.  Great brew!

Sampled this immediately after Ølfabrikken Porter and the comparison certainly didnt do this any favours. That said, this is a very good Baltic, if a bit too thin and too sweet for my taste. Black with a fair-sized head. Reeks of molasses, very rich and sweet. Sparked a childhood flashback of Halloween games involving trying to eat Scottish scones dipped in treacle dangled from strings, no hands allowed. I guess there must be some breadiness in the porter to account for the scent combination. Oily mouthfeel and for my mokney, a little skinny for a Baltic. Very sweet and treacley in the mouth, with a little lambic sourness in the finish. Smooth and dry. (Duff Homecoming gathering)

Poured black with a light brown head.  Aroma of roasted chocolate, whiskey.  Taste is very roasty and bitter with lots of chocolate and coffee coming through and just a hint of sweetness.  A bit of whiskey dryness rounds it out and makes it quite drinkable.  Good body.  Great porter.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a tan head.  The alcohol comes through strongly in the nose. Heavy body, with a great amount of bitterness that gives a great taste.  Alcohol is a bit strong in the flavor, but a good porter.

Pours a dark brown-black with a touch of ruby along the edge.  Strong alcohol nose, with a little roasted chocolate.  Oily, thick palate (a good thing).  Alcohol notes very strong, with some chocolate, and good bitterness.  Warms as it settles in.  Would rate higher but the alcohol taste is a little too much, especially for a porter.   Nevertheless - very tasty - but only on certain occasions
pours very dark choclatey looking. full bodied and rich flavor.  heavy slightly bitter stands very nicely on its own.

This is a rich, delicious, smooth, and silky Baltic Porter, coming in at a warming 7.2% abv and makes the perfect beer to match with a rich desert, or to enjoy as a night cap. 

Koff Porter pours to a beautiful, deep ebony color with a thick and creamy tan head, and a moderate amount of carbonation. The nose on this beer is fantastic with big aromas of dark chocolate, coffee, licorice, and peppery alcohol. The palate is rich and full with big dark malt, chocolate, slight roast, licorice, and coffee flavors on a silky smooth, polished body. Koff Porter finishes with more of those big chocolate and coffee notes, then ends with a dry roast and peppery alcohol finish that lingers. 

This is a world class example of Baltic Porter, one of the best in the style, and one loved by beer geeks world wide, including former presidents. This beer is best suited for cold winter months as a winter warmer, but is also the perfect beer to match with a rich, chocolate desert, and would make an idea after dinner drink or night cap. It retails in good beer markets for about $2.50-$3 a 11.2 oz or 33 cl bottle, and is well worth the price. If you can find this beer in your market, seek it out, and enjoy a world class beer from Finland.

simple but pleasant sweet (i know  you cant smell sweetness but i can tell that its going to be sweet), rich, malty, chocolatey nose. lots of bocky munich malt taken to its logical black endpoint with complementing powdery chocolate flavours. bit of warming but not abrasive alcohol. long chocolatey finish. full but not heavy - easy to sink. a mellow, well constructed beer that falls short of ohmygodness.

Thanks to Boutip for this one (I think).  Pours the color of molasses and looks just as thick.  There is a light but thick chocolate brown head.  Leaves you with some light lacing.  The aroma presents with rich malts, chocolate and carameleven hints of marshmallow.  I caught distinctive notes of the latter early on but they faded as it warmed.  The first thing I thought when I took the first sip was, Damn, should have read the description prior to drinking this one.  This was much fuller and richer than I expected, and truly seemed along the lines of an imperial stout (though not that strong or flavorful).  Chocolate and caramel malts are big and there is a light fruity presence (cherries?) that pop up in the middle.  There is a bit of sharpness that creeps out in the middle and is distracting but that fades quickly into a pleasing dark chocolate after taste.  Med-full body with a slick oily mouth feel.  Very nice.

This beer gets a lot of hype at the place that i work. Ive had it once at a bar that described it as the best porter in the world. At the time, I did not agree but I think its time to give it another shot. Pours jet black with a small beige head that quicklt dissapates. aroma of sugar, chocolate,  and smokey maltiness. flavor has more roasted malts.  really doesnt taste that complex, but i cant say its not one of the better porters i have tasted.  nice hop presence in the aftertaste.  Would like to taste other koff beers. A rare gem from finland.

Brown (black) with beige almost yellow head. Sweet aroma with some notes of chocolate and roasted malts. Medium complex flavour with roasted malts, malty sweetness and some notes of licorice and chocolate. Overall drinks rather well, well balanced but not impressive (I had expected more and this beer seems slightly overrated).

Ah, good old Koffs Porter, one of my all time favorites. Time to rate it:

Bottled. Opaque black, with big, brown foamy head, nice lacing.
Sweet, strongly roasted malt aroma, dark chocolate, some appropriate hops in the background, and a whiff of alcohol.
Flavor likewise of sweet roasted malts and dark chocolate, caramel, some hop bitter and nicely warming alcohol. Bitterish and warm alcoholic aftertaste. Very smooth, medium full body.

Simply delicious.
Dark brown/black with an average tan head. Bburnt chocolate and alcoholy burbon nose. Acidic tobacco like flavour. Thinner texture typical of a baltic proter.

black with a hint of brown on the color.  Has a bourbon and smoked wood aroma to it.  this kinda tastes like its breaking down as its from 00. It flows lightly. I got some coffee and even some liqourice and i would assume this has a tobbaco vibe as well.

Pours black with a thick bubbly tan head. Burnt, woody, chocolatey nose. Bitter, roasted, coffee-ish flavour. Somewhat acidic with some hints of tar.
Dark fruits and spices in finish.

Pours a pitch black with a ruby halo anda huge, thick, and oily brown head.  Aroma is sweet dark fruit, dark chocolate, and cake batter.  Flavor is tart, fruity, coffe, chocolate, port wine, yeasty, and full.  Hops very present, but balance well.  Fantastic stuff!

The bottle poured an almost opaque black beverage with just a hint of a garnet that came through in intense light. It had a small brown frothy head that didnt last long and left just a hint of lacing on the glass.  The aroma was wonderful. It left a strong impression of tawny port along with an alcohol kicker and notes of molasses and dried plums. The body was medium-full with lively carbonation and a lightish smooth texture. The flavor was true to the aroma. The tongue was first met with a slight, dry sweetness that is full of dried fruit and spice flavors. This matures into a long finish that turns slightly bitter and leaves a nice alcohol warmth in your chest.

Bottle. Pours an almost opaque dark brown with thin tan head. Roasted malt is about half the aroma, with the other half being chocolate, raisin, and just a touch of wood. The flavor is also largely comprised of roasted malt, along with earthy hops, coffee, baking chocolate, and just a touch of biscuit. The body is just a shade thinner than I had expected, but not enough to detract too much. Tasty brew.

Bottle. Pours black with a small head. Aroma of dried fruit, vanilla, and coffee. Flavor is heavy with roasted malt and coffee,  with a tad bit of sweetness. I t is a little thin in the mouth, but that makes this one more drinkable for a porter of this style.  Slightly bitter finish that goes down smooth. I liked this beer, but it did not knock me out.
I think my sample was quite fruity for a porter, with a little vanilla, and coffee. I was suprised how easy drinking this one was, great beer!

Bottle.  Molasses and prune aroma.  Dark black color with small brown head.  Slightly smoky, thick coffee malt flavor with a slightly sour and tart finish.  Spectacular - havent tried many of this style but this is head and shoulders above other porters and stouts I have tried.  A great beer.

Bottle. 1997 bollting (#2104). Labeled Sinebrychoff Porter IV. My first beer from Finland. Absolutely wonderful and decadent aroma. Smells of sweet coffee liqueur. Completely opaque, black body and a small, light brown head that leaves only a whispy film of head. Nice lace. Initial mouthfeel is disappointing. Whether it was the knowledge that this beer was bottled 8 years ago or not, this beer seems a little past its prime. Reminds me of Baltika 6. Appears to be a little flat. Not totally flat, however. There was a "pfffsst" when I opened the bottle. Sweet flavor, with roasted chocolate malts. Some faint smoke. Overall, I could see how this could be an impressive beer when it is in its prime; with livlier carbonation and more of the "plenty of hops" promised in the commercial description.

Sampled at Argo and Kathys 06 Holiday Gathering. Pours black with a beige head. Aroma of roasted malt and I picked up some noble hop character. Flavor has light notes of chocolate, coffee, euro hops and somewhat of a metallic finish. Medium body with soft carbonation. I guess Im not as impressed as some of the other raters on this beer.

1998 vintage.  Pours a thick black with a thin dark brown head.  Robust aroma of caramel, chocolate, coffee, vanilla, molasses, floral hops, and a hint of smoke.  Flavor is initially very sweet with dark fruits, chocolate, and grassy hops, and it finishes like bitter coffee.  Thin mouthfeel and low carbonation is the only weakness.  Overall, a tasty porter, but there is plenty of room for improvement.

33 cl bottle, 1998 vintage labelled Sinebrychoff Porter shared by jerc. Opaque dark brown colour with a mostly lasting creamy dark tan head. Dark chocolate, vinous, and lightly roasty aroma plus some citrus notes. Vinous flavour dominates, with chocolate, currant, and raisin flavours accompanying. Medium bodied, creamy with some richness, but something was missing in the mouthfeel.

Bottle... A&Ks4thAHBT... Totally black ale with a small, creamy, light brown head. The nose is chocolate, vanilla and roasted nuts. Well-balanced flavor, but it doesnt match the roastiness or richness of the aroma. A touch burnt and tangy. Medium-bodied and fizzy. Finishes crisp and fairly clean.

Bottle: Black, dark body with a light brown head.  Aroma is chocolate, roasted malt, sweet chocolate, light coffee.  Taste is light chocolate, suprisingly little roast based upon the aroma, grains, molasses, mint, all being solid real flavors.  Medium bodied, a tad light at times, but never water.

330ml bottle.Pours inky black; big thick fluffy light-tan head with exceptional retention & lacing. Nice aroma of roast grain, chocolate, coffee & black licorice. Taste is mostly dark roast grain with some chocolate, a dose of molasses and a slightly warming alcohol. Slightly thin mouthfeel, average creamy palate. Dandy stuff.

Those fins know how to make a porter.  Thick testure, bold taste, almost a chocolate toffee taste.  I remeber I tried this a long time ago and it reminded me of motor oil, but now that I have grown accustomed to the taste of fine brews, this is one of the best porters ive ever had.
Pours a nice jet black.  Aromas of chocolate/smoke/coffee.  Flavor was kinda bitter with the alcohol showing through a bit.  Nice chocolate flavors.
Bottle. Pours opaque black, brown head. Thick roasted aroma and flavour, some bitterness too. The first porter I ever tried and havent found a better one so far. Excellent beer.

Bottle. Pours black, with a tan/brown head. Aromas are roasted malt, with a little smoke and chocolate. Flavors are 
roasted malt, smoke, chocolate, coffee and hops. Body is just right, about medium. A very good porter.

Bottle. Pours black color with medium rocky brown head that diminished quickly and produced good lacing. Medium roasted malt and chocolate aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture. Good well balanced roasted malt and coffee flavor with a small bitter finish. Very good baltic.

12oz bottle from taproom in detroit. Pours a very dark black color with a foamy brown head. Nose is very roasty, smokey, malty, nutty, chocolatey..yum. Lots of chocolate and roasted malt in the flavor as well, also some coffee notes, light vanilla bean and a light bitter finish with a smooth mouthfeel.

Beer pours black with a tan head that is totall retained and heavy lacing.  Aroma is of heavy malt with notes of molasses and alcohol.  Flavor is sweet malt; light alcohol, chocolat, coffee, and some dark fruit.  Palate is medium bodied, creamy and the carbonation is soft.   Delicous porter.  Thank you Jason.

330 ml Bottle.  It popped like a wine bottle when opened.  From the bottle, a sweet caramel aroma exudes.  Dark, oily black hue with an enormous brown head.  Woodsy and chocolate, floral and figgy in the nose.  Nice lacing on the glass.  Once the head dissipated, a sugary, rum, chocolate aroma appeared.  Good effervescence and mouthfeel.  Bitter chocolate and coffee flavors.  Oily and rich.  Cedar and aniseed.  Wonderful!

Courtesy of Degarth


Malty chocolate aroma. Dark body with tan head and lacing was excelant. Head had a cream texture to it. Flavor was medium bodied and consisted of chocolate and roasted malt and wood. Dry somewhat like chocolate powder on palate.

Bottled.  Thanks go to Daniel_Brown for picking this one up for me.  A black beer with a nice long-lasting off-white head.  The aroma is quite roasty and woody with a little lactic quality to it also.  The taste is roasty and features quite bitter chocolate and coffee.  Not as full bodied as Id have liked but still plenty to enjoy.

(bottle) Highly recommended to me by a coffe lover, so I was expecting coffee flavor to the beer. This instead has a good chocolate base to the flavor. A little extra bite at the end, because of the 7.2 ABV, that I could have done without. Good though.
pours out black with a small tan head.  Flavor is choclaty with some hints of coffee as well.  Odor is that of coffee aned semi sweet chocolate.  a very goood sample of this brew.

rich creamy and dark as njight.  an awesome baltic porter.  this is something that everyone should look for, a style defining beer.  this is a beer that is damn good, and that has damn good ratings.  if you ever see a bottle of this, dont skimp out, buy one of these.  this is a porter to be reckoned with.

Bottled. Black, with brown shortlived head. Roasted coffee and chocolate in aroma. Flavor pretty much the same, roastiness even more prevalent here. Nice hop-bitterness in the finish. Excellent beer, by far the best coming out of this country.

Pours from the bottle very dark with a creamy tan head. Aromas of roasted coffee and fruit arent overbearing. Palate is heavy but smooth as silk in the mouth while tastes of coffee, chocolate and sweet malt finish with just a touch of bitter. Excellent.

Old bottle, 7-10 years old? 
Almost black with a tint of red. Bubbly brown, almost instantly disappearing, foam. Cellary nose, with traces of menthol, vinegar, cheese, cocoa powder, dried fruits to name few. Oily mouthfeel with a light staleness. Flavour from chocolate, licorice and slightly vinegary. Past its peak but nevertheless very interesting.

Hard to find under its "real" name in these listings.  The other ratings for this brewer are low.  This one isnt.  Pours a very deep thick luxurious coffee color with an almond expresso tanned creamy head.  Mouthfeel is very sloid & smooth.  Body is heavy and pleasingly so.  For 7.2 the alcohol content is well masked.  A very surprisingly strong offering.

i pawned this off on my wife,she said
mocha .i never saw it again.super dark,
dark brown head that lasts and lasts.
7.2%alc/vol.=not sweet.i doubt you
can find a better beer in finland.EXPENSIVE but worth a try.
top shelf porter!

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2009 Aromaless, really. A dark black, with dark tan head. This not particularly amazing really, but its best quality is that isnt anything that is bad about it either. These baltics are much better than the normal porter, probably because they arent as sweet.

Re-rated this by mistake and gave the same exact score for each category.
Bottle.  Black body, very dark, with medium tan head.  Good lacing.  Very roasty aroma, with chocolate and alcohol.  Flavor similar with some mocha.  Very good.

Bottle poured black with smallish brown head.
Aroma of sweet roast malts and coffee.
Medium body with a nice roasty flavor and sweet malt finish.
One of the best porters Ive had

Bottle from Birmingham Beer Festival 05. Thick, oily black, with a beige and softly fluffed head. Warm choc aroma. Great balanced and drinkable flavour: choc, with some sweet strength in and around the finish. Smooth espresso roast, but gentle. Pretty easy drinking and very tasty. Felt like it had some lightness.

Black body with a small head. Coffee and chocolate galore without much roast, very smooth. I enjoyed this one. Also faint hints of raisins. My first for the style, and for porters in general this is currently second only to Fullers.

Pours an oily black color with a large and dark tan head. Coffee, dark chocolate, and light fruit in the aroma. Very intriguing smell for a porter. Bitter black coffee start fades nicely into a sweet fruity and malty middle with hops finishing it off.  Sweet taste lingers after every sip. A very rich and complex porter. I can see myself enjoying this regularly on cold winter nights.

Medium dark brown foam.  The darkest foam I have seen so far on a stout.  Deep deep dark brown color that you cannot see through.   Malty aroma.  Malty sweet taste first on the palate that turns bitter in the appropriate place and rolls into that nicely.  The finish is bitter and lasting but not overwhelming.  Very nice.

Solid dark body with a good size dark tan head. Not a full on aroma but can pick up traces of caramel, smoke, ice coffee and cheese, more seem to appear the longer you look. Smooth in the taste there is some burnt characters, medium body, liquorice, milky coffee and some dark fruits. Cant notice the alcohol and would love to have a session on this beer.

Bottled in 98 sticker visable.  Completely dark black with a full, standard sized, light brown head.  A bit of a mix of porter and barley wine is present in the aroma.  Roasted but also fruity wineish aromas and some muted sweet malts.  Very full fetching and fairly distinct aroma.  Very strange, but good.  At first, a thing chocolate sweetness, almost like a skim chocolate milk.  It quickly gets a nice roasted malt with a wet sweet finish.  Mildly bitter but a chocolate coated sweetness quickly replaces any other flavor.  Hides any alcohol.  Very nice beer for a 6+ year beer that Im unaware of its handeling.  Happy with this purchace.

Bottle.  Black with a big rocky beige head.  Aromas are earthy, sweet with coffee and bready yeast.  Flavours are earthy, roast coffee and licourice with fruit and more roast coffee bitterness to follow.  Feels a bit thin and overly carbonated on the palate then some oiliness improves matters.  Reminded me of Old Engine Oil.

Medium sized dark tan rocky head.  Licorice, dark chocolate, and roast malt in the aroma.  Deep roastiness and chocolate give way to a large bitterness and coffee astringency in the finish.  Mouthfeel is medium heavy and smooth.

33cl - Aroma is malty dark chocolate with some roasty carmel notes.  Poured black with a huge brown head that leaves plenty of lacing.  Flavor is roasted chocolate malt, carmel, black licorice, and a touch of espresso.  A very creamy and smooth palate makes this one of the best porters Ive had.

licorice black with moderate-low carbonation. a small but persistent head. fair amount of lacing.  brandy, and some dark fruity aspects. A port wine smell is also detectable. Nice and thick with some roasty notes as well. Some port wine with a black coffee bitterness that parallels a stout in the finish. now it switches to a nice fruitiness. Wow, it completely switched flavors on the second sip! Awesome! A sweet malty beginning with a bitter coffee aftertaste. Nice and roasty, but not burnt. Smooth with dried dark fruity undertow. Great. Prickling carbonation with a moderate-full body. Very good. Just a tad overcarbonated I think, but wonderfully smooth with a nice body and crisp carbonation.  Very easy to drink. 7.2% is less than I would expect, but alcohol was used in a good way. Very nice. Had a great complexity with a smooth taste and roasty finish that was oh so nice.

Unknown vintage.  Nothing on the bottle.  Pours to a huge bubbly creamy with awesome lacing and a reverse cascading head atop a black body.
