Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter, slightly husky.

Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.

Its been 10 years since Ive had this, but alas its no longer the 4+ brew I remember. Always passed this up in the States cause theyre notoriously old bottles, but this is seemingly pretty fresh. Still looks great, but the aroma and mouth experience are both just ok...the malt is pretty simple and a bit rough. Oh well.

Poured dark, tan head that didn't last long.  Very complex aroma.  Complexity moves right along to the first sip as well.  Seems to be a lot of flavors there that I can't quite distinquish.  A bit of aftertaste, but nothing nasty or bitter.  I would seek this out again, not often, but as a nice flavorful change to what else is out there.
UPDATED: AUG 5, 2006 Dark black with a big brown head. Chocolate and fruit/berry aroma. Flavor is sweet, chocolate burnt malt , toffee and caramel. Very dry finish.

A little suprised about all of the high ratings of this beer.  I thought it very average and uncomplex for a Eastern porter.  One word that epitomizes this brew is "chewy", it's almost like biting into a piece of toffee.  Some nice roasted caramel tones.  But not overly impressive.

Bittersweet chocolate plunders this beer. No nose at first...it only appears after things start to warm up. Very drinkable, but nothing special until halfway through the bottle. the alcohol starts to tingle more and bittersweet accents start to roll out everywhere.

This one pours a jet black color with a medium sized, dark tan, lasting head. The aroma is sweet with touches of alcohol, molasses, and coffee. Full bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and soft carbonation, the flavor is sweet with malts and touches of roasted chocolate and coffee. The finish is sweet with a touch of bitterness. One of the better porters I have had, ranks up there with Anchor and Rogue as my favorites.

(Bottle). Pitch black porter, even held against the light. Tan head. Complex aroma of coffee, cocoa, dried fruits, ensilage(!) and oak. The full and rich flavour has coffee, bitter chocolate and loads of roasted maltiness. Not too sweet, just the right bitterness in the aftertaste. This must be a world class porter!
Dark as night, with a heavy alc. taste. It had a nice taste of hops, very small head.

Bottled in 2000,if that makes a difference?Nearly no head what so ever but what was there was chocolate brownand fast fadeing,color was coal mine dark,aroma was malty ,chocolatey and coffeeish.Flavor was really big raisins,coffee very lite,some prunes possibly,and some hints of chocolate.This is a big on flavor beer that the flavor and after taste seem to go on forever and at 7% alc. its well hidden and very unnoticable.the maltyness is huge with a nice full feel in the mouth,with an after taste that is sweet and fruity  the finish is definately mellow sweet this is a new favorite for me to bad the price tag is so high at 6 bucks a bottle you couldn't afford to drink them for too long.

Eclipse black color. Small head. Aroma is fruity (raisins and apricots). A lighter bodied porter. Roaster malts are sweet, choclately and fruity. Hops are mild. Very drinkable. Touch of oak and smoke. Smooth. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2003 This brew has a very nice aroma for this Porter. Extremely dark brown color with a small light head filled with a mixture of all sizes of bubbles. Very heavy taste with an initial bite that soon fades. Subsequent tastes are not as bitter. All in all one of the better Porters I have tasted. Hotstuff did not rate the beer as she felt it had chocolate in it.

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2003   Dark body and head. Chocolatey, slightly sweet aroma. Strong chocolate/nutty malt flavor. Incredibly soft mouthfeel. I'd like to see a bit more going on in the malt, but the chocolate that is there is powerful and delicious. Slightly woody/smokey, but mostly chocolatey. Extremely malty and well balanced, a great porter.

1996 Vintage: Heavy mapley aroma, and dark color with quick head. The flavor was woody and broad, with hints of coffee and chocolate. The 2003 is much drier with much less body.  Again, one to let age.

Pours an almost opaque dark brown, with a slight garnet tinge to it.  Head is medium in size, dark tan in color, leaves good lacing.  Aroma is roasted malt, caramel, light dough, and mild chocolate.  Flavor is roasted malts, coffee, bitter chocolate.  Body is medium, medium carbonation, and goes down quite smooth.

This is a huge beer with tons of flavor.  Chocolate, fruits and roasty flavors are overwhelmed by raisin which lasts through the finish.  I would prefer the raisin were toned down a bit. But still a monster beer.

Tan, mostly diminishing head.  Coffee aroma.  Good color that made me want to drink it.  Rather sweet, with coffee and chocolate high lights.  I was pleasantly surprised, I just took a stab when I picked this up at liquormart.  Porters are fastly becoming my favorite.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2008 Opaque black body topped by a thick tan lasting head with lots of lace.  One of the darkest beers I’ve ever seen.  Sweet banana nut like aroma similar to baking banana bread with a slight smokey and chocolate background.  Slightly sweet banana nut like malt flavor with a smokey chocolate background and finish.  Great flavor.  slightly dry and full bodied.
Wonderfully dark with a huge head.  Aroma of molasses, some caramel, a bit syruppy.  Appropriate palate.  Nicely roasted flavour, with some coffee and vanilla, more caramel.

Bottled in 1997 # 3057. In my case head was minimal. Deep brown, almost opaque. Highly refined rich and complex aroma. High notes of alcohol that merge well with biter chocolate and pinch of sugar. Mild on front but when it spreads around your mouth you can appreciate its nobility.  Neither heavy nor crude. Nice example, rather smoother thank most porters.
extremely dark in color.  The aroma is very complex, vanilla, caramel come through.  The palate is a bit light for my taste, however the complexity of the dark malt is really wonderfull.
This is a classic, strong in alcahol, yet not alcaholic, deep rich, an almost coffeeish taste.  More complexity and flavor than dry stouts which makes this beer more enjoyable.
almost as dark as coal,good aroma . roasty chocolate malt, quite dry, malt grapes, nicely burned flavour.a touch of licorice,and a dash of coffee,nice porter.
Black with huge rocky dense head.Malt nose. Good roasted flavor. In some circles it is actually considered an imperial stout

1997.  Black, dark head.  Light chocolate, roast and sweet malt in the nose.  Nicely roasty, hints of chocolate a touch of smoke and slightly sweet.  Very well balanced and complex, top notch baltic porter.  A clinic for many porters today.

Dark brown,thick,lasting bubbly head atop a midnight thick oily body; strongly roasty, vinous, spicy nose with chocolate becoming more pronounced as it warms.  Flavor at first seems rather mild, very creamy and chocolaty, but gets more intense and alcoholic, with coffee and some plumminess appearing; a bit too flat and smooth on the end, could have used some kick.  Overall, a topnotch effort; I have to find more of these baltics (alas, not in VT).
I found it intense yet enjoyable. Chocolate overtones but not overdone, smooth and slight bitter finish. Good but not great!!

From El Kabongs kitchen (what kind of handle is that, Hal?).  A very busy porter from the rootbeer and caramel openign notes through the more interesting fruity and chocolate tones on into a alkalinity that I dont care much for.
Killer porter. Smooth, dark and oily with some fruity presence. Took me a few sips to get used to it, but it was very pleasent to drink. A fine porter.
This is a great just because there are no flaws at all in this beer.  It is so smooth, so dark, and so rich that words cannot even describe.  This is one of my favorite beers.

Deep, dark, almost black in color, pours thick with a thin thick foam. Strong smells of chocolate, coffee, and toffee are all present in this beer. The taste is thick and sweet, with hints of the toffee and coffee, smooth with a sweet after taste. A good all around porter.
Very, very smooth. Has a very burnt flavor to it, with a coffee/chocolate aftertaste. Dark yellow head, and left a nice lace on the glass.
Wonderful aroma of roasting coffee and semi-sweet chocolate. Flavor is a bit too thin, though, dominated by a dry chocolatiness and some coffee flavors, with a lightly bitter finish.
Bottle.  Fully black with a laced brown head.  An intense aroma full of coffee, molasses, highlights of fruit, and some alcohol.  A nice full body that leaves a refined malty chocolate feel.
Deep brown almost black color, rich coffee and cocoa flavor and aroma.  Another great porter!
Black as night, big dark tan head, sweet vinous nose. Rich, slightly sweet, with dark fruits and wine, dark chocolate and perhaps coffee, and a hint of bitterness on the finish. Very smooth. Yum.

Good stuff.  Deep black with a mocha head.  Nose is sweet and roasty.  Flavor is very full and rich, lots of sweet malts nicely balanced with a dark chocolate/coffee bitterness.  Full and vinous, lovely creamy texture.  Nice.

Damn, if its not one of the most beautiful beers Ive ever seen!!!  Black with a purply red reflection. Rocky mountain tan head, brussels lace for days.  Fruity and coffee nose with hints of alcohol coming through.   Big on flavor and aftertaste.  Sweet malts are just as strong as the roasted malts. Oaky/winey as it warms and very filling.  Very, very good.

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2005 Rerate Excellent tar black pour, khaki head, cocoa and olive oil aroma, sweet pipe tobacco flavor, thick creamy mouthfeel -still excellent - just a bit too liberal and generous in my earlier ratings Original 4.5 Pours with a clean coffee/chocolate aroma and gives way to a black as night oily masterpiece. Absolutely no "dirt" aftertaste that some Porters tend to have. Rates almost up there with Fullers in my humble opinion. Ill look for this again - found out of town.

Not quite as good as Fullers but this Porter is no slouch. Pours a nice oily black with a pretty milk-chocolate brown head. Aroma of espresso and chocolate. Very robust flavor with a slightly sharp aftertaste, but overall the finish is warm and smooth. Very good!
Excellent porter. Nice fruity raisiny flavor. I also  picked up some butterscotch flavors.
Nice, deep color. Full body. Roasty and nutty without the bitter taste.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2004 Great porter. In fact, it's the best porter I've had (except Fuller's). Great roasty, nutty flavor. Opaque black, nice tan head, full, thick body. Wonderful

Rerate: 4/30/04
First of all, I like this better than Fuller's London porter. It has a beautiful licorice core...very hearty. Still one of the best porters I've had.
Very dark with nice tan head. Nice mouthfeel. Very good indeed.
Black pour with a big tan head. Nose of raisins and roasted malt. Big palate,full bodied and velvety. Big porter that is definately worth trying.

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2006 2000 vintage sampled of 11/9/06: Pours an opaque black with light carbonation and a thin ring of dark tan head.  Complex sweet dark caramel aroma has some brown sugar notes and soy with a good amount of dark chocolate.  Body starts with a good dark malty sweetness, some oxidization notes and a softer roasty finish.  Seems to have aged quite well.

Original rating 8/28/02: Robust to the max.  Thick rich black appearance with a pillowy tan head. Hardly any recognition of its relatively high alcohol content.  Great sweet aftertaste masks the alcohol and gives it a full, almost oily mouthfeel.  Complex malty undertones bring out a roasted flavor that is nicely hopped. Chocolate coffee lingers in the finish. If they used the same yeast as guiness, they did a much better job.
Full of semi sweet chocolate and rich expresso notes-whoa! I cant believe I just wrote that! Very Good Beer- Strong!
A very good strong porter.  A nice flavorand easy drinking.

My first Baltic Porter! I hope this is typical of the style. A frothy tan head sits atop a very dark and cloudy(?) brew. Rich burnt taste and ever so slightly swampy. Like the black mud by trout creek. One of the top 10 Ive had. Purchased at Surdyks in Minneapolis, MN
A very nice porter.  Good aroma, great appearance.  Excellent feel in the mouth.  Good sweetness at first and a good roasted aftertaste.  A very nice Porter.

Aroma is roasty, bready, vinous and earthy.  Outright black in color with a dark tan, lasting head.  Baltic Porter indeed.  Flavor is reasonably complex, with highly roasted, grainy, almost burnt maltiness leading the way, some molasses and date with esters and sweetness lingering on.  Definite oily consistency, with a pronounced, dryish bitterness towards the finish, which is quite long.  This is very tasty, even more so than I remember.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2006 Black with huge,pefectly beaded,tiny bubbled,pillowy head. Vinous,oaky,roasted,coffe bean aromas.Alcohol is underlying in aroma.Full,and oily palate.Flavors are roasty,vinous and some coffee and charcoal flavors.Finish is burnt and lighly hoppy(dectable). There is also a little alcohol hidden in the finish.Flavors seem to be ever changing in a good way.Not for your average porter fan.Intensely,vinous.As it warms more greatly burnt and warming.

Extremely dark brown in color - almost black. Medium-sized dark tan head. Complex aromas of roasted coffee, sweet malt, caramel and a bit nutty. Thick and chewy palate - full bodied. Big flavors: roasted coffee, sweet malt, a bit winey - slight touch of hops and acidity to balance out the sweetness. 

This is an awesome porter - one of the best Ive sampled. Huge and complex flavors. Call this an IMPERIAL PORTER as its similar to Imperial Stouts in terms of its big and bold style. Try this!!

Very viscous pour, the deepest brown, of course.  The aroma is pleasant, slightly vinous, but not medicinal.  A multitude of flavors here:  molasses, coffee grounds, carob and raisins, all ending in a chalky, dry flourish.  Belies its relatively high ABV.  Normally I let porters warm up to room temp, but I couldnt wait that long between each sip, so that makes this a quaffer porter?  Much like a stout overall, this is a very nice beer.
Fruity malt and burnt alcohol aroma. High alcohol comes through on the palate, a little pastey with strong chocolate and dark roasted aftertaste.

(1997 bottle)  Black with nice mocha head.  Chocolate licorice aroma.  Rich coffee chocolate flavor.  Little if any bitterness until the aftertaste, which also has a slight alcohol tinge.  Very stouty porter, quite delicious.
Thick and dark.  Roasted aroma.  The flavor is full and rich with a slight smoky flavor lurking in there.  Very good beer.
Thick rich aroma with substantial hops.  Flavor is full of dark roasty and smoky malts, with a touch of liquorice.  An excellent after dinner drink.
chocolate ice cream scoop head.  Oaty, syrupy feel with semi-sweet finish.  hides its strenght like a 16 year old hideing his stash from his mother.  1996 bottle.
just after looking and smelling it I dont think Id have a problem sticking someone with a shiv to get one, sooo good
very dark colour, big creamy black-tainted head, nice lace, black chocolate and dark fruity aroma, full-bodied, strong bitterness with a long dry chocolate finish

Deep dark brown to black, the head is generous and chocolate colored, lace is heavy and in sheets upon the Chalice. Nose is earthy, malt, caramel and bitter sweet chocolate. Begins a nice sweet malt, the top medium to full, the finish is dry, lightly acidic, slight hint of hops, a very decent porter in my book.

man was this tasty. this was the 96 edition. kinda tasted like a barly wine with a porter mix. nice chocolaty roasted flavor. aroma was very potent of malts with a hint of alcohol. same goes for the after taste.
A nice black porter, and not quite as sweet as Carnegie.  Very smooth and pleasant Baltic Porter-style brew thats relatively easy to find.

Pours black, but not opaque with smallish tan head. Nice roastiness in aroma and flavor. The bitterness rides on top of a marshmallow kind of flavor. The feel of the beer leaves the palate quickly and leaves little aftertaste. Fairly clean profile.

This smooth, oil colored stout resembles the baltic and imperial porter styles. A pleasant sweet sharpness of malt in the aroma--a pungence present in the flavor as well.  Sharp attributes, but well balanced and with an underlying coffee tinged alchohol punch that lends a hearty fullness to the body.

Black, black, black in color. Head was thick and brown. Aromas of oak and anise- bit of sourness for good measure. Immediately surprisingly thin. Not much complexity and the alcohol is perhaps too well hidden. Warm chocolate notes begin to emerge past the 1/2 mark.

Okay, first off, wasnt expecting a Finnish beer. Love the people, but never heard much about beer from them. A nice dark color, a decent head(but didnt hold). Nice flavor with some flavor elements that I have quite figured out yet. Worth checking out.

Chocolate, coffee and dark rye aroma. Darkest brown, a bit of scarlet at the sides of the glass. Big creamy cappuccino head. Roasted coffee flavour, also pontefrat cakes, (liquorice) oily, but good, dark lace all over the place. Malty sweetness, a thick textured offering  (fork or spoon?) Sensational, Thanks again Crind!

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2003 (Re-rate)I can only guess my first rating was from a vintage bottle(will try a vintage bottle to confirm) Almost black, very nice light brown head and lace. Nose of chocolate, coffee, black malt and molasses. Huge palate of malts, sweet molasses,burnt fruitcake, coffee, hops, touch of smoke and a bit of cardboard. Oily and hugely rich body that sticks all the way through. An immense porter that should be savored.
Easily the best Baltic porter that Ive had.

Pleasant chocolate malty nose.  Very thick bodied with a medium frothy head.  Cannot see through the glass!  Excellent roasted malt flavor that is still abundant well after the glass has been returned to the table.  Highly recommended brew!

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2004 Two years past its best by date. One of the best Baltic aromas i've experienced.  Mild, yet stunningly complex with soft notes of baked black currants and molasses. Hints of almonds, butter, concorde grapes, roasty whiffs of malt, and vinous notes; some cardboard (oxidation) as the beer warms.    Creamy, feathery soft carbonation. Starts moderately roasty followed up with rich maltiness, charred chewiness, and an acidic, abundant black licorice finish. Still gaining much more complexity after many years in the bottle and becoming more elegant, seemingly by the day. Thus far, the most elegant Baltic Porter out there.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: A nice roasted almost smoky flavor. Coffee undertones with a nice bitter flavor.  An excellent porter

Rerate: Rich, burnt, and slightly smoky. Strong mouthfeel with a sharp bitterness. Well-made, semi-complex and interesting. Very woodsy tasting. Bold, with a somewhat dry finish. A little reminiscent of cold coffee.

deep brown, almost black, short lived beige head, nose hinted at coffee bitter cocoa and plums.
nice full bodied palate, sweet and malty but with a surprisingly bitter aftertaste.
A very nice baltic porter
Very dark brown ... almost opaque.  Thinish head that disipates quickly.  Smooth full body.  Mocha notes, sweet, with toffee characteristics.  Very nice porter.
Not the best Porter Ive had, but well worth trying to find.  A hint of molasses flavor originally, but the aftertaste is smooth and pleasant.
Another fine porter. Not quite up to standards of Londons or Carnegie, but still a top notch example.

This is available in bottles at North Peak Brewing in Traverse City, Michigan, and from El Kabongs fridge, also in Traverse City.  It is big, black, and fruity (smoked plums and dried cherries).  The body slides darkly away from you as you go, but its a pretty intriguing beer.

Im all over the board with this one. I get so aggravated when I cant pin one aspect of the aroma down, but theres something down in there, fruity, sweet, as Ducati mentions, maybe raisin? Delightfully thick and hearty, all the roasted tones you would expect. Excellent bitter coffee at the very end of a substantial finish.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Oily, woody and coffeeish with a flowery aroma.  A warm finish for the colder nights.
notes of coffee, fairly decent...first non-US porter ive tried..nice opaque color. decent beige head.
UPDATED: FEB 5, 2004 Gets a 2 in flavor for being godawful bitter.  Keep away.  Definitely can taste chocolate and possibly licorice.

Nice Baltic porter.  The aroma has hints of raisons, licorice, dark munich malt and some higher alcohols.  The flavor is malty sweet with a chocolate malt dryness.  After taste is on malty side.  A very nice beer.

Well it set itself just perfect. Black, tan foam sheeting up through a creamy body, smelled a bit like coffee from further away. Then I nosed in and there was something very interesting in there -- a bit of sasparilla and then the rest of a good porter. Roasty, malty honts of cacao, coffee. The texture and sweetness are just about perfect. If Jen wasnt so good at detecting high wort temp errors this wouldve tasted even better.

an amazingly wonderful example of the Baltic porter.  Smokey, chocolately with a touch of bitterness.  Thin, brown head that lasts the entire glass.  If anything were to be added or taken away it would ruin this fine, fine beer.
UPDATED: JUL 23, 2003 7/23/03: Slight sourness in the ending.  Plum notes, otherwise same as before. Old rating:  Wow.  Black. Heavy, warming, chocolates. Drink it warm.
First baltic porter Ive had. nice black body, good beer for a cold Michigan winter evening

An interesting beer.  A whisky malt/alcohol aroma with hints of raisin, plum, and chocolate.  The beer is black in colour with a nice tan head.  Silky mouthfeel.  The flavour is chcolatey, figgy, plummy, and slightly bitter.  My first expirience with this style and it was quite good.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2004 A very good, if not a little weak, Baltic Porter. Lots of roasted malts and very little bitterness. An oily smooth after-taste. abv is well hidden. (3.7) Re-rate. The importers, B. United International, were far thinking enough to have taken a number of cases of this beer and lay them down. That was in 1996. How is it 7 years later? Marvelous. Pours very black with a nice beaded head and a huge roasted nose. The hop oils are still around in the nose as well. This is so smooth that it is hard to remember that it is a strong ale. The hops are very subdued after 7 years and the once burnt flavors have matured into an amazingly pleasant roastiness. As balnced a strong porter as one will find.
Black, rich, warming and fullbodied. This is just perfect for a cold Finnish winter night.
A very nice chocolatey full-bodied porter, perfect for chilly winter evenings. Good balance of the ingredients. Pleasant lingering palate.
One of the best = rivals D. Carnegie
Taste was too salty chocolate after the great initial look and smell.
Jet black, warmingly fruity ( burnt fruitcake, raisins), long, long finish.  The best of the Baltic porters, and Ive had a few.  Se on hyvää olutta.
Muy bien.

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2006 First off, Im now a full-fledged convert
of the Baltic porter style.  Anyway, this beer is strong and chocolatey.  Aroma is full of dark fruits.  Flavor is almost like cocoa, with more dark fruits.  Very nice opaque dark brown color, with a dark tan head.  Excellent strong porter. 
Rerate: 2000 bottle sampled in 2006. Poured at 60 deg F, probably warmed close to 70 deg by the end of the glass. Potent but balanced aroma of roast/ash and bittersweet cocoa, some soy sauce (in a good way). First sip is a revelation as that brown foam passes the lips like whipped cream, setting the stage for a full velvety mouthfeel. Despite the fullness, its barely sweet at all, with a nice dry roasty finish and notes of coffee in between. I love this combination of full body and dryness, and its so hard to find. Outstanding when fresh, beautiful aged.
Pours with a small head, poor retention.  Has an annoying woody aftertaste.  I would recommend at near room temperature.
